      </div>
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">
       Etymology
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_place_names" title="New Zealand place names">
       New Zealand place names
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius,_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png">
        <img alt="brown square paper with Dutch writing and a thick red, curved line" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="532" data-file-width="684" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius%2C_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png/220px-Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius%2C_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius%2C_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png/330px-Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius%2C_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius%2C_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png/440px-Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius%2C_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Detail_of_1657_map_Polus_Antarcticus_by_Jan_Janssonius,_showing_Nova_Zeelandia.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Detail from a 1657 map showing the western coastline of "Nova Zeelandia"
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
       Dutch
      </a>
      explorer
      <a href="/wiki/Abel_Tasman" title="Abel Tasman">
       Abel Tasman
      </a>
      sighted New Zealand in 1642 and called it
      <i>
       Staten Landt
      </i>
      , supposing it was connected to a landmass of the same name at the southern tip of South America.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
       <a href="#cite_note-18">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1645, Dutch
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cartographers" title="Cartographers">
       cartographers
      </a>
      renamed the land
      <i>
       Nova Zeelandia
      </i>
      after the
      <a href="/wiki/Seventeen_Provinces" title="Seventeen Provinces">
       Dutch province
      </a>
      of
      <a href="/wiki/Zeeland" title="Zeeland">
       Zeeland
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StatenLandt_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-StatenLandt-19">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      British explorer
      <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">
       James Cook
      </a>
      subsequently
      <a href="/wiki/Anglicisation" title="Anglicisation">
       anglicised
      </a>
      the name to New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        [n 7]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Aotearoa" title="Aotearoa">
        Aotearoa
       </a>
      </i>
      (often translated as "land of the long white cloud")
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing200341_22-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing200341-22">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      is the current Māori name for New Zealand. It is unknown whether Māori had a name for the whole country before the arrival of Europeans, with
      <i>
       Aotearoa
      </i>
      originally referring to just the
      <a href="/wiki/North_Island" title="North Island">
       North Island
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHayMaclaganGordon200872_23-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHayMaclaganGordon200872-23">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Māori had several traditional names for the two main islands, including
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Te_Ika-a-M%C4%81ui" title="Te Ika-a-Māui">
        Te Ika-a-Māui
       </a>
      </i>
      (the fish of
      <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ui_(M%C4%81ori_mythology)" title="Māui (Māori mythology)">
       Māui
      </a>
      ) for the North Island and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Te_Waipounamu" title="Te Waipounamu">
        Te Waipounamu
       </a>
      </i>
      (the waters of
      <a href="/wiki/Pounamu" title="Pounamu">
       greenstone
      </a>
      ) or
      <i>
       Te Waka o Aoraki
      </i>
      (the canoe of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aoraki" title="Aoraki">
       Aoraki
      </a>
      ) for the
      <a href="/wiki/South_Island" title="South Island">
       South Island
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith20056_24-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith20056-24">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Early European maps labelled the islands North (North Island), Middle (South Island) and South (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stewart_Island_/_Rakiura" title="Stewart Island / Rakiura">
       Stewart Island / Rakiura
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1830, maps began to use North and South to distinguish the two largest islands and by 1907, this was the accepted norm.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_name_26-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZ_name-26">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Geographic_Board" title="New Zealand Geographic Board">
       New Zealand Geographic Board
      </a>
      discovered in 2009 that the names of the North Island and South Island had never been formalised, and names and alternative names were formalised in 2013. This set the names as North Island or Te Ika-a-Māui, and South Island or Te Waipounamu.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Note that for each island, either its English or Māori name can be used, or both can be used together.
     </p>
     <div style="clear:left;">
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_Zealand" title="History of New Zealand">
       History of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Polynesian_Migration.svg">
        <img alt="One set of arrows point from Taiwan to Melanesia to Fiji/Samoa and then to the Marquesas Islands. The population then spread, some going south to New Zealand and others going north to Hawai'i. A second set start in southern Asia and end in Melanesia." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="553" data-file-width="553" height="280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Polynesian_Migration.svg/280px-Polynesian_Migration.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Polynesian_Migration.svg/420px-Polynesian_Migration.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Polynesian_Migration.svg/560px-Polynesian_Migration.svg.png 2x" width="280"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Polynesian_Migration.svg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people" title="Māori people">
         Māori people
        </a>
        are most likely descended from people who emigrated from
        <a href="/wiki/Taiwan" title="Taiwan">
         Taiwan
        </a>
        to
        <a href="/wiki/Melanesia" title="Melanesia">
         Melanesia
        </a>
        and then travelled east through to the
        <a href="/wiki/Society_Islands" title="Society Islands">
         Society Islands
        </a>
        . After a pause of 70 to 265 years, a new wave of exploration led to the discovery and settlement of New Zealand.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
         <a href="#cite_note-28">
          [21]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand was one of the last major landmasses settled by humans.
      <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">
       Radiocarbon dating
      </a>
      , evidence of
      <a href="/wiki/Deforestation" title="Deforestation">
       deforestation
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        [22]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA" title="Mitochondrial DNA">
       mitochondrial DNA
      </a>
      variability within
      <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people" title="Māori people">
       Māori
      </a>
      populations
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
       <a href="#cite_note-30">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
      suggest New Zealand was first settled by Eastern
      <a href="/wiki/Polynesians" title="Polynesians">
       Polynesians
      </a>
      between 1250 and 1300,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith20056_24-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith20056-24">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNAS2008_31-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PNAS2008-31">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
      concluding a long series of voyages through the southern Pacific islands.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Over the centuries that followed, these settlers developed a distinct culture now known as Māori. The population was divided into
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Iwi" title="Iwi">
        iwi
       </a>
      </i>
      (tribes) and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Hap%C5%AB" title="Hapū">
        hapū
       </a>
      </i>
      (subtribes) who would sometimes cooperate, sometimes compete and sometimes fight against each other. At some point, a group of Māori migrated to the
      <a href="/wiki/Chatham_Islands" title="Chatham Islands">
       Chatham Islands
      </a>
      (which they named
      <i>
       Rēkohu
      </i>
      ) where they developed their distinct
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Moriori_people" title="Moriori people">
       Moriori
      </a>
      culture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        [26]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Moriori population was all but wiped out between 1835 and 1862, largely because of
      <a href="/wiki/Taranaki_(iwi)" title="Taranaki (iwi)">
       Taranaki
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people" title="Māori people">
       Māori
      </a>
      invasion and enslavement in the 1830s, although European diseases also contributed. In 1862, only 101 survived and the last known full-blooded Moriori died in 1933.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
       <a href="#cite_note-35">
        [28]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The first
      <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Europe" title="Ethnic groups in Europe">
       Europeans
      </a>
      known to have reached New Zealand were Dutch explorer
      <a href="/wiki/Abel_Tasman" title="Abel Tasman">
       Abel Tasman
      </a>
      and his crew in 1642.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith200523_36-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith200523-36">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In a hostile encounter, four crew members were killed and at least one Māori was hit by
      <a href="/wiki/Canister_shot" title="Canister shot">
       canister shot
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
       <a href="#cite_note-37">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Europeans did not revisit New Zealand until 1769 when British explorer
      <a href="/wiki/James_Cook" title="James Cook">
       James Cook
      </a>
      mapped almost the entire coastline.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith200523_36-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMein_Smith200523-36">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following Cook, New Zealand was visited by numerous European and North American
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_whaling" title="History of whaling">
       whaling
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Seal_hunting" title="Seal hunting">
       sealing
      </a>
      and trading ships. They traded European food, metal tools, weapons and other goods for timber, Māori food, artifacts and water.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2003122_38-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2003122-38">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The introduction of the potato and the
      <a href="/wiki/Musket" title="Musket">
       musket
      </a>
      transformed Māori agriculture and warfare. Potatoes provided a reliable food surplus, which enabled longer and more sustained military campaigns.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
       <a href="#cite_note-39">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The resulting intertribal
      <a href="/wiki/Musket_Wars" title="Musket Wars">
       Musket Wars
      </a>
      encompassed over 600 battles between 1801 and 1840, killing 30,000–40,000 Māori.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
       <a href="#cite_note-40">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From the early 19th century, Christian
      <a href="/wiki/Missionary" title="Missionary">
       missionaries
      </a>
      began to settle New Zealand, eventually
      <a href="/wiki/Religious_conversion" title="Religious conversion">
       converting
      </a>
      most of the Māori population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Māori population declined to around 40% of its pre-contact level during the 19th century; introduced diseases were the major factor.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
       <a href="#cite_note-42">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Treatyofwaitangi.jpg">
        <img alt="A torn sheet of paper" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5788" data-file-width="3091" height="318" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Treatyofwaitangi.jpg/170px-Treatyofwaitangi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Treatyofwaitangi.jpg/255px-Treatyofwaitangi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Treatyofwaitangi.jpg/340px-Treatyofwaitangi.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Treatyofwaitangi.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Waitangi sheet from the
        <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi" title="Treaty of Waitangi">
         Treaty of Waitangi
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1788 Captain
      <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Phillip" title="Arthur Phillip">
       Arthur Phillip
      </a>
      assumed the position of
      <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_New_South_Wales" title="Governor of New South Wales">
       Governor
      </a>
      of the new British colony of
      <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_New_South_Wales" title="Colony of New South Wales">
       New South Wales
      </a>
      which according to his commission included New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AustHeritage_43-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AustHeritage-43">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The British Government appointed
      <a href="/wiki/James_Busby" title="James Busby">
       James Busby
      </a>
      as British Resident to New Zealand in 1832 following a petition from northern Māori.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Busby_44-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Busby-44">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1835, following an announcement of impending French settlement by
      <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Thierry" title="Charles de Thierry">
       Charles de Thierry
      </a>
      , the nebulous
      <a href="/wiki/United_Tribes_of_New_Zealand" title="United Tribes of New Zealand">
       United Tribes of New Zealand
      </a>
      sent a
      <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Independence_of_New_Zealand" title="Declaration of the Independence of New Zealand">
       Declaration of the Independence
      </a>
      to King
      <a href="/wiki/William_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="William IV of the United Kingdom">
       William IV of the United Kingdom
      </a>
      asking for protection.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Busby_44-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Busby-44">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Ongoing unrest, the proposed settlement of New Zealand by the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Company" title="New Zealand Company">
       New Zealand Company
      </a>
      (which had already sent its first ship of surveyors to buy land from Māori) and the dubious legal standing of the Declaration of Independence prompted the
      <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Office" title="Colonial Office">
       Colonial Office
      </a>
      to send Captain
      <a href="/wiki/William_Hobson" title="William Hobson">
       William Hobson
      </a>
      to claim sovereignty for Great Britain and negotiate a treaty with the Māori.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        [38]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi" title="Treaty of Waitangi">
       Treaty of Waitangi
      </a>
      was first signed in the
      <a href="/wiki/Bay_of_Islands" title="Bay of Islands">
       Bay of Islands
      </a>
      on 6 February 1840.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wilson2009_46-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wilson2009-46">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In response to the New Zealand Company's attempts to establish an independent settlement in
      <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">
       Wellington
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and French settlers purchasing land in
      <a href="/wiki/Akaroa" title="Akaroa">
       Akaroa
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48">
       <a href="#cite_note-48">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Hobson declared British sovereignty over all of New Zealand on 21 May 1840, even though copies of the Treaty were still circulating throughout the country for Māori to sign.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
       <a href="#cite_note-49">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With the signing of the Treaty and declaration of sovereignty the number of immigrants, particularly from the United Kingdom, began to increase.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
       <a href="#cite_note-50">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay,_New_Zealand.jpg">
        <img alt="Black and white engraving depicting a crowd of people" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4300" data-file-width="6000" height="201" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay%2C_New_Zealand.jpg/280px-1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay%2C_New_Zealand.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay%2C_New_Zealand.jpg/420px-1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay%2C_New_Zealand.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay%2C_New_Zealand.jpg/560px-1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay%2C_New_Zealand.jpg 2x" width="280"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1863_Meeting_of_Settlers_and_Maoris_at_Hawke%27s_Bay,_New_Zealand.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A meeting of European and Māori inhabitants of
        <a href="/wiki/Hawke%27s_Bay_Province" title="Hawke's Bay Province">
         Hawke's Bay Province
        </a>
        . Engraving, 1863.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand, still part of the colony of New South Wales, became a separate
      <a href="/wiki/Crown_colony" title="Crown colony">
       Colony
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_New_Zealand" title="Colony of New Zealand">
       of New Zealand
      </a>
      on 1 July 1841.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
       <a href="#cite_note-51">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The colony gained a
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Constitution_Act_1852" title="New Zealand Constitution Act 1852">
       representative government in 1852
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/1st_New_Zealand_Parliament" title="1st New Zealand Parliament">
       first Parliament
      </a>
      met in 1854.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G_and_N_52-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-G_and_N-52">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1856 the colony effectively became self-governing, gaining responsibility over all domestic matters other than
      <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples" title="Indigenous peoples">
       native
      </a>
      policy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G_and_N_52-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-G_and_N-52">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (Control over native policy was granted in the mid-1860s.)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G_and_N_52-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-G_and_N-52">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following concerns that the South Island might form a separate colony, premier
      <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Domett" title="Alfred Domett">
       Alfred Domett
      </a>
      moved a resolution to transfer the capital from Auckland to a locality near the
      <a href="/wiki/Cook_Strait" title="Cook Strait">
       Cook Strait
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
       <a href="#cite_note-53">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Wellington was chosen for its harbour and central location, with parliament officially sitting there for the first time in 1865. As immigrant numbers increased, conflicts over land led to the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Wars" title="New Zealand Wars">
       New Zealand Wars
      </a>
      of the 1860s and 1870s, resulting in the loss and confiscation of much Māori land.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1891 the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Liberal_Party" title="New Zealand Liberal Party">
       Liberal
      </a>
      Party led by
      <a href="/wiki/John_Ballance" title="John Ballance">
       John Ballance
      </a>
      came to power as the first organised political party. The
      <a href="/wiki/Liberal_Government_of_New_Zealand" title="Liberal Government of New Zealand">
       Liberal Government
      </a>
      , later led by
      <a href="/wiki/Richard_Seddon" title="Richard Seddon">
       Richard Seddon
      </a>
      , passed many important social and economic measures. In 1893 New Zealand was the first nation in the world to grant all
      <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_New_Zealand" title="Women's suffrage in New Zealand">
       women the right to vote
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
       <a href="#cite_note-55">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and in 1894 pioneered the
      <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Conciliation_and_Arbitration_Act_1894" title="Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1894">
       adoption of compulsory arbitration between employers and unions
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
       <a href="#cite_note-56">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1898 Seddon's government passed the Old-age Pensions Act of 1898, the first general pensions scheme in the British Empire.
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1907, at the request of the New Zealand Parliament, King
      <a href="/wiki/Edward_VII" title="Edward VII">
       Edward VII
      </a>
      proclaimed New Zealand a
      <a href="/wiki/Dominion_of_New_Zealand" title="Dominion of New Zealand">
       dominion
      </a>
      within the
      <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">
       British Empire
      </a>
      , reflecting its self-governing status. Accordingly, the title "Dominion of New Zealand" dates from 1907.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
       <a href="#cite_note-57">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1947 the country adopted the
      <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_Adoption_Act_1947" title="Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1947">
       Statute of Westminster
      </a>
      , confirming that the British Parliament could no longer legislate for New Zealand without the consent of New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-G_and_N_52-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-G_and_N-52">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Early in the 20th century, New Zealand was involved in world affairs, fighting in the
      <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_New_Zealand_in_World_War_I" title="Military history of New Zealand in World War I">
       First
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of New Zealand during World War II">
       Second World Wars
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and suffering through the
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
       Great Depression
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
       <a href="#cite_note-60">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The depression led to the election of the
      <a href="/wiki/First_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand" title="First Labour Government of New Zealand">
       first Labour government
      </a>
      and the establishment of a comprehensive
      <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">
       welfare state
      </a>
      and a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protectionist" title="Protectionist">
       protectionist
      </a>
      economy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand experienced increasing prosperity following World War II
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [55]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and Māori began to leave their traditional rural life and move to the cities in search of work.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
       <a href="#cite_note-63">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_protest_movement" title="Māori protest movement">
       Māori protest movement
      </a>
      developed, which criticised
      <a href="/wiki/Eurocentrism" title="Eurocentrism">
       Eurocentrism
      </a>
      and worked for greater recognition of
      <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_culture" title="Māori culture">
       Māori culture
      </a>
      and the Treaty of Waitangi.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1975, a
      <a href="/wiki/Waitangi_Tribunal" title="Waitangi Tribunal">
       Waitangi Tribunal
      </a>
      was set up to investigate alleged breaches of the Treaty, and it was enabled to investigate historic grievances in 1985.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wilson2009_46-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Wilson2009-46">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The government has negotiated
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi_claims_and_settlements" title="Treaty of Waitangi claims and settlements">
       settlements of these grievances
      </a>
      with many iwi, although
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_foreshore_and_seabed_controversy" title="New Zealand foreshore and seabed controversy">
       Māori claims to the foreshore and seabed
      </a>
      have proved controversial in the 2000s.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">
       Politics
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_New_Zealand" title="Politics of New Zealand">
       Politics of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Government">
       Government
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg">
        <img alt="A smiling woman wearing a purple dress and matching hat." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2400" data-file-width="1820" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg/170px-Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg/255px-Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg/340px-Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Queen_Elizabeth_II_March_2015.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">
         Elizabeth II
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queen_of_New_Zealand" title="Queen of New Zealand">
         Queen of New Zealand
        </a>
        since 1952.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand is a
      <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">
       constitutional monarchy
      </a>
      with a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy" title="Parliamentary democracy">
       parliamentary democracy
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
      although
      <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_New_Zealand" title="Constitution of New Zealand">
       its constitution
      </a>
      is
      <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">
       not codified
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_factsheet_66-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist_factsheet-66">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">
       Elizabeth II
      </a>
      is the
      <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_New_Zealand" title="Monarchy of New Zealand">
       Queen of New Zealand
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">
       head of state
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67">
       <a href="#cite_note-67">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Queen is represented by the
      <a href="/wiki/Governor-General_of_New_Zealand" title="Governor-General of New Zealand">
       Governor-General
      </a>
      , whom she appoints on the advice of the
      <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand" title="Prime Minister of New Zealand">
       Prime Minister
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
       <a href="#cite_note-68">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
       <a href="#cite_note-69">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Governor-General can exercise the Crown's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prerogative_powers" title="Prerogative powers">
       prerogative powers
      </a>
      , such as reviewing cases of injustice and making appointments of
      <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_the_Crown" title="Minister of the Crown">
       ministers
      </a>
      , ambassadors and other key public officials,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
       <a href="#cite_note-70">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and in rare situations, the
      <a href="/wiki/Reserve_power" title="Reserve power">
       reserve powers
      </a>
      (e.g. the power to dissolve Parliament or refuse the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Assent" title="Royal Assent">
       Royal Assent
      </a>
      of a
      <a href="/wiki/Bill_(law)" title="Bill (law)">
       bill
      </a>
      into law).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reserve_Powers_71-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-reserve_Powers-71">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The powers of the Queen and the Governor-General are limited by constitutional constraints and they cannot normally be exercised without the advice of
      <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_New_Zealand" title="Cabinet of New Zealand">
       Cabinet
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reserve_Powers_71-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-reserve_Powers-71">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament_facts_72-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-parliament_facts-72">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Parliament" title="New Zealand Parliament">
       New Zealand Parliament
      </a>
      holds
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_power" title="Legislative power">
       legislative power
      </a>
      and consists of the Queen and the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_House_of_Representatives" title="New Zealand House of Representatives">
       House of Representatives
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament_facts_72-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-parliament_facts-72">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It also included an upper house, the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Legislative_Council" title="New Zealand Legislative Council">
       Legislative Council
      </a>
      , until this was abolished in 1950.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament_facts_72-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-parliament_facts-72">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_sovereignty" title="Parliamentary sovereignty">
       supremacy of Parliament
      </a>
      , over the Crown and other government institutions, was established in England by the
      <a href="/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689" title="Bill of Rights 1689">
       Bill of Rights 1689
      </a>
      and has been ratified as law in New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament_facts_72-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-parliament_facts-72">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The House of Representatives is democratically elected and a Government is formed from the party or
      <a href="/wiki/Coalition_government" title="Coalition government">
       coalition
      </a>
      with the majority of seats.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parliament_facts_72-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-parliament_facts-72">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      If no majority is formed a
      <a href="/wiki/Minority_government" title="Minority government">
       minority government
      </a>
      can be formed if support from other parties during
      <a href="/wiki/Confidence_and_supply" title="Confidence and supply">
       confidence and supply
      </a>
      votes is assured. The Governor-General appoints ministers under advice from the Prime Minister,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
      who is by convention the
      <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_leader" title="Parliamentary leader">
       Parliamentary leader
      </a>
      of the governing party or coalition. Cabinet, formed by ministers and led by the Prime Minister (currently
      <a href="/wiki/John_Key" title="John Key">
       John Key
      </a>
      ), is the highest policy-making body in government and responsible for deciding significant government actions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By
      <a href="/wiki/Convention_(norm)" title="Convention (norm)">
       convention
      </a>
      , members of cabinet are bound by
      <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_collective_responsibility" title="Cabinet collective responsibility">
       collective responsibility
      </a>
      to decisions made by cabinet.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:John_Key_headshot.jpg">
        <img alt="A smiling man wearing a white shirt with a green tie and black jacket." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="430" data-file-width="315" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/John_Key_headshot.jpg/170px-John_Key_headshot.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/John_Key_headshot.jpg/255px-John_Key_headshot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5c/John_Key_headshot.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:John_Key_headshot.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/John_Key" title="John Key">
         John Key
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand" title="Prime Minister of New Zealand">
         Prime Minister of New Zealand
        </a>
        since 2008.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Almost all
      <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_New_Zealand" title="Elections in New Zealand">
       parliamentary general elections
      </a>
      between
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_1853" title="New Zealand general election, 1853">
       1853
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_1993" title="New Zealand general election, 1993">
       1993
      </a>
      were held under the
      <a href="/wiki/First-past-the-post_voting" title="First-past-the-post voting">
       first-past-the-post voting
      </a>
      system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-road_76-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-road-76">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The elections since 1930 have been dominated by two political parties,
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_National_Party" title="New Zealand National Party">
       National
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Labour_Party" title="New Zealand Labour Party">
       Labour
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-road_76-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-road-76">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_1996" title="New Zealand general election, 1996">
       1996 election
      </a>
      , a form of
      <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">
       proportional representation
      </a>
      called
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mixed_Member_Proportional" title="Mixed Member Proportional">
       Mixed Member Proportional
      </a>
      (MMP) has been used.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_factsheet_66-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist_factsheet-66">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Under the MMP system each person has two votes; one is for electoral seats (including some
      <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_electorates" title="Māori electorates">
       reserved for Māori
      </a>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
       <a href="#cite_note-77">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the other is for a party. Since the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_2014" title="New Zealand general election, 2014">
       2014 election
      </a>
      , there have been 71 electorate seats (which includes 7 Māori electorates), and the remaining 49 seats are assigned so that representation in parliament reflects the party vote, although a party has to win one electoral seat or 5% of the total party vote before it is eligible for these seats.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
       <a href="#cite_note-78">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Between March 2005 and August 2006 New Zealand became the only country in the world in which all the highest offices in the land—Head of State, Governor-General, Prime Minister,
      <a href="/wiki/Speaker_of_the_New_Zealand_House_of_Representatives" title="Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives">
       Speaker
      </a>
      and Chief Justice—were occupied simultaneously by women.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
       <a href="#cite_note-79">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg">
        <img alt="A block of buildings fronted by a large statue" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2557" data-file-width="3297" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg/220px-Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg/330px-Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg/440px-Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Seddon_Statue_in_Parliament_Grounds.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A statue of
        <a href="/wiki/Richard_Seddon" title="Richard Seddon">
         Richard Seddon
        </a>
        , the "
        <a href="/wiki/Beehive_(New_Zealand)" title="Beehive (New Zealand)">
         Beehive
        </a>
        " (Executive Wing), and
        <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Parliament_Buildings" title="New Zealand Parliament Buildings">
         Parliament House
        </a>
        (right), in Parliament Grounds, Wellington.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Judges and judicial officers are appointed non-politically and under strict rules regarding
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tenure" title="Tenure">
       tenure
      </a>
      to help maintain constitutional independence from the government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_factsheet_66-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist_factsheet-66">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This theoretically allows the judiciary to interpret the law based solely on the legislation enacted by Parliament without other influences on their decisions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
       <a href="#cite_note-80">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Committee_of_the_Privy_Council" title="Judicial Committee of the Privy Council">
       Privy Council
      </a>
      in London was the country's final court of appeal until 2004, when it was replaced with the newly established
      <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_New_Zealand" title="Supreme Court of New Zealand">
       Supreme Court of New Zealand
      </a>
      . The judiciary, headed by the
      <a href="/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_New_Zealand" title="Chief Justice of New Zealand">
       Chief Justice
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
       <a href="#cite_note-81">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      includes the
      <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeal_of_New_Zealand" title="Court of Appeal of New Zealand">
       Court of Appeal
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_New_Zealand" title="High Court of New Zealand">
       High Court
      </a>
      , and subordinate courts.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist_factsheet_66-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist_factsheet-66">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand is identified as one of the world's most stable and well-governed nations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
       <a href="#cite_note-82">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2011
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the country was ranked fifth in the strength of its democratic institutions
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
       <a href="#cite_note-83">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and first in government transparency and lack of corruption.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
       <a href="#cite_note-84">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand has a high level of civic participation, with 79% voter turnout during the most recent elections, compared to an OECD average of 72%. Furthermore, 67% of New Zealanders say they trust their political institutions, far higher than the OECD average of 56%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
       <a href="#cite_note-85">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/International_rankings_of_New_Zealand" title="International rankings of New Zealand">
       International rankings of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations_and_the_military">
       Foreign relations and the military
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_New_Zealand" title="Foreign relations of New Zealand">
       Foreign relations of New Zealand
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Defence_Force" title="New Zealand Defence Force">
       New Zealand Defence Force
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_(20).jpg">
        <img alt="A soldier in a green army uniform faces forwards" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_%2820%29.jpg/220px-ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_%2820%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_%2820%29.jpg/330px-ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_%2820%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_%2820%29.jpg/440px-ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_%2820%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ANZAC_Day_service_at_the_National_War_Memorial_-_Flickr_-_NZ_Defence_Force_(20).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Anzac_Day" title="Anzac Day">
         Anzac Day
        </a>
        service at the National War Memorial.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Early colonial New Zealand allowed the British Government to determine external trade and be responsible for foreign policy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
       <a href="#cite_note-86">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 1923 and 1926
      <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Conference" title="Imperial Conference">
       Imperial Conferences
      </a>
      decided that New Zealand should be allowed to negotiate their own political
      <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">
       treaties
      </a>
      and the first commercial treaty was ratified in 1928 with Japan. On 3 September 1939 New Zealand allied itself with Britain and
      <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">
       declared war
      </a>
      on Germany with Prime Minister
      <a href="/wiki/Michael_Joseph_Savage" title="Michael Joseph Savage">
       Michael Savage
      </a>
      proclaiming, "Where she goes, we go; where she stands, we stand."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87">
       <a href="#cite_note-87">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg">
        <img alt="A squad of men kneel in the desert sand while performing a war dance" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2999" data-file-width="3040" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg/220px-E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg/330px-E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg/440px-E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:E_003261_E_Maoris_in_North_Africa_July_1941.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_Battalion" title="Māori Battalion">
         Māori Battalion
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Haka" title="Haka">
         haka
        </a>
        in Egypt, 1941.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In 1951 the United Kingdom became increasingly focused on its European interests,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
       <a href="#cite_note-88">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while New Zealand joined
      <a href="/wiki/Australia%E2%80%93New_Zealand_relations" title="Australia–New Zealand relations">
       Australia
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="New Zealand–United States relations">
       United States
      </a>
      in the
      <a href="/wiki/ANZUS" title="ANZUS">
       ANZUS
      </a>
      security treaty.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
       <a href="#cite_note-89">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The influence of the United States on New Zealand weakened following protests over the
      <a href="/wiki/Vietnam_War" title="Vietnam War">
       Vietnam War
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
       <a href="#cite_note-90">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the refusal of the United States to admonish France after the
      <a href="/wiki/Sinking_of_the_Rainbow_Warrior" title="Sinking of the Rainbow Warrior">
       sinking of the
       <i>
        Rainbow Warrior
       </i>
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
       <a href="#cite_note-91">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
      disagreements over environmental and agricultural trade issues and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Zealand%27s_nuclear-free_zone" title="New Zealand's nuclear-free zone">
       New Zealand's nuclear-free policy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
       <a href="#cite_note-92">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
       <a href="#cite_note-93">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite the US's suspension of ANZUS obligations the treaty remained in effect between New Zealand and Australia, whose foreign policy has followed a similar historical trend.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
       <a href="#cite_note-94">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Close political contact is maintained between the two countries, with
      <a href="/wiki/Closer_Economic_Relations" title="Closer Economic Relations">
       free trade agreements
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Trans-Tasman_Travel_Arrangement" title="Trans-Tasman Travel Arrangement">
       travel arrangements
      </a>
      that allow citizens to visit, live and work in both countries without restrictions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_in_brief_95-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZ_in_brief-95">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 2013, there are about 650,000 New Zealand citizens living in Australia, which is about 15% of the population of New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96">
       <a href="#cite_note-96">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      65,000 Australians live in New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_in_brief_95-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZ_in_brief-95">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand has a strong presence among the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Island" title="Pacific Island">
       Pacific Island
      </a>
      countries. A large proportion of New Zealand's aid goes to these countries and many Pacific people migrate to New Zealand for employment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
       <a href="#cite_note-97">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Permanent migration is regulated under the 1970 Samoan Quota Scheme and the 2002 Pacific Access Category, which allow up to 1,100 Samoan nationals and up to 750 other Pacific Islanders respectively to become permanent New Zealand residents each year. A seasonal workers scheme for temporary migration was introduced in 2007 and in 2009 about 8,000 Pacific Islanders were employed under it.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
       <a href="#cite_note-98">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand is involved in the
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islands_Forum" title="Pacific Islands Forum">
       Pacific Islands Forum
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">
       Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">
       Association of Southeast Asian Nations
      </a>
      Regional Forum (including the
      <a href="/wiki/East_Asia_Summit" title="East Asia Summit">
       East Asia Summit
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_in_brief_95-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZ_in_brief-95">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand is also a member of the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_and_the_United_Nations" title="New Zealand and the United Nations">
       United Nations
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
       <a href="#cite_note-99">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">
       Commonwealth of Nations
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
       <a href="#cite_note-100">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
       Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
       <a href="#cite_note-101">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Five_Power_Defence_Arrangements" title="Five Power Defence Arrangements">
       Five Power Defence Arrangements
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
       <a href="#cite_note-102">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The New Zealand Defence Force has three branches: the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_New_Zealand_Navy" title="Royal New Zealand Navy">
       Royal New Zealand Navy
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Army" title="New Zealand Army">
       New Zealand Army
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Royal_New_Zealand_Air_Force" title="Royal New Zealand Air Force">
       Royal New Zealand Air Force
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
       <a href="#cite_note-103">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand's
      <a href="/wiki/National_security" title="National security">
       national defence
      </a>
      needs are modest because of the unlikelihood of direct attack,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
      although it does have a global presence. The country fought in both world wars, with notable campaigns in
      <a href="/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign" title="Gallipoli Campaign">
       Gallipoli
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Crete" title="Battle of Crete">
       Crete
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
       <a href="#cite_note-105">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Battle_of_El_Alamein" title="Second Battle of El Alamein">
       El Alamein
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
       <a href="#cite_note-106">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Monte_Cassino" title="Battle of Monte Cassino">
       Cassino
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107">
       <a href="#cite_note-107">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Gallipoli campaign played an important part in fostering New Zealand's
      <a href="/wiki/Nation" title="Nation">
       national identity
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108">
       <a href="#cite_note-108">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and strengthened the
      <a href="/wiki/Australian_and_New_Zealand_Army_Corps" title="Australian and New Zealand Army Corps">
       ANZAC
      </a>
      tradition it shares with Australia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
       <a href="#cite_note-110">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to Mary Edmond-Paul, "World War I had left scars on New Zealand society, with nearly 18,500 in total dying as a result of the war, more than 41,000 wounded, and others affected emotionally, out of an overseas fighting force of about 103,000 and a population of just over a million."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111">
       <a href="#cite_note-111">
        [104]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand also played key parts in the naval
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_River_Plate" title="Battle of the River Plate">
       Battle of the River Plate
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112">
       <a href="#cite_note-112">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">
       Battle of Britain
      </a>
      air campaign.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        [106]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114">
       <a href="#cite_note-114">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During World War II, the United States had more than 400,000 American military personnel stationed in New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gov_115-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-gov-115">
        [108]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In addition to Vietnam and the two world wars, New Zealand fought in the
      <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">
       Korean War
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Second_Boer_War" title="Second Boer War">
       Second Boer War
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116">
       <a href="#cite_note-116">
        [109]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Malayan_Emergency" title="Malayan Emergency">
       Malayan Emergency
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">
       Gulf War
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%93present)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–present)">
       Afghanistan War
      </a>
      . It has contributed forces to several regional and global peacekeeping missions, such as those in
      <a href="/wiki/Cyprus_dispute" title="Cyprus dispute">
       Cyprus
      </a>
      , Somalia,
      <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">
       Bosnia and Herzegovina
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">
       Sinai
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Angolan_Civil_War" title="Angolan Civil War">
       Angola
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cambodian%E2%80%93Vietnamese_War" title="Cambodian–Vietnamese War">
       Cambodia
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Iraq_War" title="Iran–Iraq War">
       Iran–Iraq
      </a>
      border,
      <a href="/wiki/Bougainville_Campaign" title="Bougainville Campaign">
       Bougainville
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Operation_Astute" title="Operation Astute">
       East Timor
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/Solomon_Islands#Civil_war" title="Solomon Islands">
       Solomon Islands
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Deployments_118-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Deployments-118">
        [111]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand also sent a unit of army engineers to help rebuild
      <a href="/wiki/Iraq" title="Iraq">
       Iraqi
      </a>
      infrastructure for one year during the
      <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">
       Iraq War
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand ranks 8th in the
      <a href="/wiki/Center_for_Global_Development" title="Center for Global Development">
       Center for Global Development
      </a>
      's 2012
      <a href="/wiki/Commitment_to_Development_Index" title="Commitment to Development Index">
       Commitment to Development Index
      </a>
      , which ranks the world's most developed countries on their dedication to policies that benefit poorer nations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119">
       <a href="#cite_note-119">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand is considered the fourth most peaceful country in the world according to the 2016
      <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">
       Global Peace Index
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120">
       <a href="#cite_note-120">
        [113]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Local_government_and_external_territories">
       Local government and external territories
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_New_Zealand" title="Local government in New Zealand">
       Local government in New Zealand
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Realm_of_New_Zealand" title="Realm of New Zealand">
       Realm of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Realm_of_New_Zealand-2.PNG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="269" data-file-width="540" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Realm_of_New_Zealand-2.PNG/400px-Realm_of_New_Zealand-2.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bf/Realm_of_New_Zealand-2.PNG 1.5x" width="400"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Realm_of_New_Zealand-2.PNG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Realm_of_New_Zealand" title="Realm of New Zealand">
         Realm of New Zealand
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The early European settlers divided New Zealand into
      <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_New_Zealand" title="Provinces of New Zealand">
       provinces
      </a>
      , which had a degree of autonomy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nine_provinces_121-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nine_provinces-121">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Because of financial pressures and the desire to consolidate railways, education, land sales and other policies, government was centralised and the provinces were abolished in 1876.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a result, New Zealand now has no separately represented
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subnational_entity" title="Subnational entity">
       subnational entities
      </a>
      . The provinces are remembered in
      <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_New_Zealand" title="Public holidays in New Zealand">
       regional public holidays
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123">
       <a href="#cite_note-123">
        [116]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and sporting rivalries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        [117]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Since 1876, various councils have administered local areas under legislation determined by the central government.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nine_provinces_121-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nine_provinces-121">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1989, the government reorganised local government into the current two-tier structure of
      <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_New_Zealand" title="Regions of New Zealand">
       regional councils
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Territorial_Authorities_of_New_Zealand" title="Territorial Authorities of New Zealand">
       territorial authorities
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-merga_mania_126-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-merga_mania-126">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_former_territorial_authorities_in_New_Zealand" title="List of former territorial authorities in New Zealand">
       249 municipalities
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-merga_mania_126-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-merga_mania-126">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      that existed in 1975 have now been consolidated into 67 territorial authorities and 11 regional councils.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Subnat_Pop_Ests_127-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Subnat_Pop_Ests-127">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The regional councils' role is to regulate "the natural environment with particular emphasis on
      <a href="/wiki/Resource_Management_Act_1991" title="Resource Management Act 1991">
       resource management
      </a>
      ",
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-merga_mania_126-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-merga_mania-126">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while territorial authorities are responsible for sewage, water, local roads, building consents and other local matters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Smelt_2009_128-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Smelt_2009-128">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-glossary_129-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-glossary-129">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Five of the territorial councils are
      <a href="/wiki/Unitary_authority" title="Unitary authority">
       unitary authorities
      </a>
      and also act as regional councils.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-glossary_129-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-glossary-129">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The territorial authorities consist of 13 city councils, 53 district councils, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Chatham_Islands" title="Chatham Islands">
       Chatham Islands
      </a>
      Council. While officially the Chatham Islands Council is not a unitary authority, it undertakes many functions of a regional council.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
       <a href="#cite_note-130">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand is one of 16
      <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">
       realms within the Commonwealth
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131">
       <a href="#cite_note-131">
        [124]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GG_constitution_132-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GG_constitution-132">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Realm_of_New_Zealand" title="Realm of New Zealand">
       Realm of New Zealand
      </a>
      is the territory over which the Queen of New Zealand is sovereign and comprises New Zealand,
      <a href="/wiki/Tokelau" title="Tokelau">
       Tokelau
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Ross_Dependency" title="Ross Dependency">
       Ross Dependency
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">
       Cook Islands
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Niue" title="Niue">
       Niue
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GG_constitution_132-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GG_constitution-132">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Cook Islands and Niue are self-governing states in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freely_associated_state" title="Freely associated state">
       free association
      </a>
      with New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        [126]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The New Zealand Parliament cannot pass legislation for these countries, but with their consent can act on behalf of them in foreign affairs and defence. Tokelau is a
      <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_list_of_Non-Self-Governing_Territories" title="United Nations list of Non-Self-Governing Territories">
       non-self-governing territory
      </a>
      that uses the New Zealand flag and anthem, but is administered by a council of three elders (one from each Tokelauan
      <a href="/wiki/Atoll" title="Atoll">
       atoll
      </a>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
       <a href="#cite_note-135">
        [128]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        [129]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Ross_Dependency" title="Ross Dependency">
       Ross Dependency
      </a>
      is New Zealand's
      <a href="/wiki/Territorial_claims_in_Antarctica" title="Territorial claims in Antarctica">
       territorial claim in Antarctica
      </a>
      , where it operates the
      <a href="/wiki/Scott_Base" title="Scott Base">
       Scott Base
      </a>
      research facility.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        [130]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand citizenship law treats all parts of the realm equally, so most people born in New Zealand, the Cook Islands, Niue, Tokelau and the Ross Dependency before 2006 are New Zealand citizens. Further conditions apply for those born from 2006 onwards.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="navbox collapsible autocollapse">

          </li>

            </abbr>
           </a>

        </div>

        </span>
       </th>
      </tr>

         </a>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

        </a>
       </th>

       </td>

       </td>

        </a>
       </td>
       <td rowspan="3">
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2" style="background:#eef;">
        <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_outlying_islands" title="New Zealand outlying islands">

        </a>
        outside any regional authority
        <br/>
        (the
        <a href="/wiki/Kermadec_Islands" title="Kermadec Islands">

        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Three_Kings_Islands" title="Three Kings Islands">
         Three Kings Islands
        </a>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Subantarctic_Islands" title="New Zealand Subantarctic Islands">

        </a>
        )
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2" style="background:#eef;">

        </a>
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2" style="background:#eef;">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1800" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Flag_of_Tokelau.svg/23px-Flag_of_Tokelau.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Flag_of_Tokelau.svg/35px-Flag_of_Tokelau.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Flag_of_Tokelau.svg/46px-Flag_of_Tokelau.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>

        </a>
       </td>

        </span>
       </td>

         </a>

       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>

        </a>
       </th>
       <td style="background:#f4f4ff;">

       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr style="line-height:12px;font-size:90%;">

        Notes
       </th>
       <td style="background:#fcfcff;">
        Some districts lie in more than one region
       </td>
       <td style="background:#fcfcff;">
        These combine the regional and the territorial authority levels in one
       </td>
       <td style="background:#fcfcff;">
        Special territorial authority
       </td>
       <td colspan="1" style="background:#fcfcff;">
        The outlying
        <a href="/wiki/Solander_Islands" title="Solander Islands">
         Solander Islands
        </a>
        form part of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southland_Region" title="Southland Region">
         Southland Region
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="background:#fcfcff;">
        New Zealand's
        <a href="/wiki/Territorial_claims_in_Antarctica" title="Territorial claims in Antarctica">
         Antarctic territory
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="background:#fcfcff;">
        <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_list_of_Non-Self-Governing_Territories" title="United Nations list of Non-Self-Governing Territories">
