        </a>
        of New Zealand
       </td>
       <td colspan="2" style="background:#fcfcff;">
        States in
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freely_associated_state" title="Freely associated state">
         free association
        </a>
        with New Zealand
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">
       Environment
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_New_Zealand" title="Environment of New Zealand">
       Environment of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">
       Geography
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_New_Zealand" title="Geography of New Zealand">
       Geography of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      <img alt="" data-file-height="1376" data-file-width="1024" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/12px-Commons-logo.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/18px-Commons-logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4a/Commons-logo.svg/24px-Commons-logo.svg.png 2x" width="12"/>
      See also:
      <a class="extiw" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Atlas_of_New_Zealand" title="commons:Atlas of New Zealand">
       Atlas of New Zealand
      </a>
      at
      <a href="/wiki/Wikimedia_Commons" title="Wikimedia Commons">
       Wikimedia Commons
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg">
        <img alt="Photo of New Zealand from space." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5600" data-file-width="4200" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg/170px-New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg/255px-New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg/340px-New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_23_October_2002.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The snow-capped
        <a href="/wiki/Southern_Alps" title="Southern Alps">
         Southern Alps
        </a>
        dominate the South Island, while the North Island's
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Auckland_Peninsula" title="North Auckland Peninsula">
         Northland Peninsula
        </a>
        stretches towards the subtropics.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mt_Cook,_NZ.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="4608" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Mt_Cook%2C_NZ.jpg/220px-Mt_Cook%2C_NZ.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Mt_Cook%2C_NZ.jpg/330px-Mt_Cook%2C_NZ.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Mt_Cook%2C_NZ.jpg/440px-Mt_Cook%2C_NZ.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         <a href="/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook" title="Aoraki / Mount Cook">
          Aoraki / Mount Cook
         </a>
         is the highest point of New Zealand, at 3,754 metres.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4272" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg/220px-New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg/330px-New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg/440px-New_Zealand_moutain_ranges.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The Southern Alps stretch for 500 kilometres down the South Island.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand is located near the centre of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_hemisphere" title="Water hemisphere">
       water hemisphere
      </a>
      and is made up of two main islands and a number of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islands_of_New_Zealand" title="Islands of New Zealand">
       smaller islands
      </a>
      . The two main islands (the
      <a href="/wiki/North_Island" title="North Island">
       North Island
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Te_Ika-a-M%C4%81ui" title="Te Ika-a-Māui">
       Te Ika-a-Māui
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/South_Island" title="South Island">
       South Island
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Te_Waipounamu" title="Te Waipounamu">
       Te Waipounamu
      </a>
      ) are separated by the
      <a href="/wiki/Cook_Strait" title="Cook Strait">
       Cook Strait
      </a>
      , 22 kilometres (14 mi) wide at its narrowest point.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139">
       <a href="#cite_note-139">
        [132]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Besides the North and South Islands, the five largest inhabited islands are Stewart Island, the Chatham Islands,
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Barrier_Island" title="Great Barrier Island">
       Great Barrier Island
      </a>
      (in the
      <a href="/wiki/Hauraki_Gulf" title="Hauraki Gulf">
       Hauraki Gulf
      </a>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACC_Hauraki_140-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ACC_Hauraki-140">
        [133]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/D%27Urville_Island,_New_Zealand" title="D'Urville Island, New Zealand">
       d'Urville Island
      </a>
      (in the
      <a href="/wiki/Marlborough_Sounds" title="Marlborough Sounds">
       Marlborough Sounds
      </a>
      )
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141">
       <a href="#cite_note-141">
        [134]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Waiheke_Island" title="Waiheke Island">
       Waiheke Island
      </a>
      (about 22 km (14 mi) from central Auckland).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Akld_coastguard_distances_142-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Akld_coastguard_distances-142">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country's islands lie between latitudes
      <a href="/wiki/29th_parallel_south" title="29th parallel south">
       29°
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/53rd_parallel_south" title="53rd parallel south">
       53°S
      </a>
      , and longitudes
      <a href="/wiki/165th_meridian_east" title="165th meridian east">
       165°
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/179th_meridian_east" title="179th meridian east">
       179°E
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand is long and narrow (over 1,600 kilometres (990 mi) along its north-north-east axis with a maximum width of 400 kilometres (250 mi)),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        [136]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with about 15,000 km (9,300 mi) of coastline
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and a total land area of 268,000 square kilometres (103,500 sq mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Because of its far-flung outlying islands and long coastline, the country has extensive marine resources. Its
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exclusive_Economic_Zone" title="Exclusive Economic Zone">
       Exclusive Economic Zone
      </a>
      is one of the largest in the world, covering more than 15 times its land area.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mfe_146-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-mfe-146">
        [139]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The South Island is the largest landmass of New Zealand, and is divided along its length by the
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_Alps" title="Southern Alps">
       Southern Alps
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147">
       <a href="#cite_note-147">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are 18 peaks over 3,000 metres (9,800 ft), the highest of which is
      <a href="/wiki/Aoraki_/_Mount_Cook" title="Aoraki / Mount Cook">
       Aoraki / Mount Cook
      </a>
      at 3,754 metres (12,316 ft).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGarden200552_148-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGarden200552-148">
        [141]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Fiordland" title="Fiordland">
       Fiordland
      </a>
      's steep mountains and deep
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fiord" title="Fiord">
       fiords
      </a>
      record the extensive ice age glaciation of this south-western corner of the South Island.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The North Island is less mountainous but is
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volcanism_of_New_Zealand" title="Volcanism of New Zealand">
       marked by volcanism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
       <a href="#cite_note-150">
        [143]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The highly active
      <a href="/wiki/Taupo_Volcanic_Zone" title="Taupo Volcanic Zone">
       Taupo Volcanic Zone
      </a>
      has formed a large
      <a href="/wiki/North_Island_Volcanic_Plateau" title="North Island Volcanic Plateau">
       volcanic plateau
      </a>
      , punctuated by the North Island's highest mountain,
      <a href="/wiki/Mount_Ruapehu" title="Mount Ruapehu">
       Mount Ruapehu
      </a>
      (2,797 metres (9,177 ft)). The plateau also hosts the country's largest lake,
      <a href="/wiki/Lake_Taupo" title="Lake Taupo">
       Lake Taupo
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151">
       <a href="#cite_note-151">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      nestled in the
      <a href="/wiki/Caldera" title="Caldera">
       caldera
      </a>
      of one of the world's most active
      <a href="/wiki/Supervolcano" title="Supervolcano">
       supervolcanoes
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        [145]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The country owes its varied topography, and perhaps even its emergence above the waves, to the dynamic boundary it straddles between the
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Plate" title="Pacific Plate">
       Pacific
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Indo-Australian_Plate" title="Indo-Australian Plate">
       Indo-Australian Plates
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keith_2009_153-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Keith_2009-153">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand is part of
      <a href="/wiki/Zealandia_(continent)" title="Zealandia (continent)">
       Zealandia
      </a>
      , a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Microcontinent" title="Microcontinent">
       microcontinent
      </a>
      nearly half the size of Australia that gradually submerged after breaking away from the
      <a href="/wiki/Gondwana" title="Gondwana">
       Gondwanan
      </a>
      supercontinent.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
       <a href="#cite_note-154">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      About 25 million years ago, a shift in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plate_tectonic" title="Plate tectonic">
       plate tectonic
      </a>
      movements began to
      <a href="/wiki/Kaikoura_Orogeny" title="Kaikoura Orogeny">
       contort and crumple
      </a>
      the region. This is now most evident in the Southern Alps, formed by
      <a href="/wiki/Continental_collision" title="Continental collision">
       compression of the crust
      </a>
      beside the
      <a href="/wiki/Alpine_Fault" title="Alpine Fault">
       Alpine Fault
      </a>
      . Elsewhere the plate boundary involves the
      <a href="/wiki/Subduction" title="Subduction">
       subduction
      </a>
      of one plate under the other, producing the
      <a href="/wiki/Puysegur_Trench" title="Puysegur Trench">
       Puysegur Trench
      </a>
      to the south, the
      <a href="/wiki/Hikurangi_Trench" title="Hikurangi Trench">
       Hikurangi Trench
      </a>
      east of the North Island, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Kermadec_Trench" title="Kermadec Trench">
       Kermadec
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Tonga_Trench" title="Tonga Trench">
       Tonga Trenches
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        [148]
       </a>
      </sup>
      further north.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Keith_2009_153-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Keith_2009-153">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand and Australia are both part of the wider regions known as
      <a href="/wiki/Australasia" title="Australasia">
       Australasia
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">
       Oceania
      </a>
      . The term
      <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">
       Oceania
      </a>
      is often used to denote the region encompassing the Australian continent, New Zealand and various islands in the Pacific Ocean that are not included in the seven-continent model.
     </p>
     <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
      <li class="gallerycaption">
       Landscapes of New Zealand

         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
       Climate
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_New_Zealand" title="Climate of New Zealand">
       Climate of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand has a mild and temperate
      <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
       maritime
      </a>
      climate (
      <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
       Köppen
      </a>
      : Cfb) with mean annual temperatures ranging from 10 °C (50 °F) in the south to 16 °C (61 °F) in the north.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Historical
      <a href="/wiki/Maxima_and_minima" title="Maxima and minima">
       maxima and minima
      </a>
      are 42.4 °C (108.32 °F) in
      <a href="/wiki/Rangiora" title="Rangiora">
       Rangiora
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Canterbury,_New_Zealand" title="Canterbury, New Zealand">
       Canterbury
      </a>
      and −25.6 °C (−14.08 °F) in
      <a href="/wiki/Ranfurly,_New_Zealand" title="Ranfurly, New Zealand">
       Ranfurly
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Otago" title="Otago">
       Otago
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-niwa_157-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-niwa-157">
        [150]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Conditions vary sharply across regions from extremely wet on the
      <a href="/wiki/West_Coast,_New_Zealand" title="West Coast, New Zealand">
       West Coast
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/South_Island" title="South Island">
       South Island
      </a>
      to almost
      <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">
       semi-arid
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Central_Otago" title="Central Otago">
       Central Otago
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/Mackenzie_Basin" title="Mackenzie Basin">
       Mackenzie Basin
      </a>
      of inland Canterbury and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subtropical" title="Subtropical">
       subtropical
      </a>
      in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Auckland_Peninsula" title="North Auckland Peninsula">
       Northland
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
       <a href="#cite_note-158">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Of the seven largest cities,
      <a href="/wiki/Christchurch" title="Christchurch">
       Christchurch
      </a>
      is the driest, receiving on average only 640 millimetres (25 in) of rain per year and Wellington the wettest, receiving almost twice that amount.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
       <a href="#cite_note-159">
        [152]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch all receive a yearly average of more than 2,000 hours of sunshine. The southern and south-western parts of the South Island have a cooler and cloudier climate, with around 1,400–1,600 hours; the northern and north-eastern parts of the South Island are the sunniest areas of the country and receive about 2,400–2,500 hours.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
       <a href="#cite_note-160">
        [153]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The general snow season is about early June until early October in the South Island. Snowfall is less common on the North Island, although it does occur.
     </p>
     <ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
      <li class="gallerycaption">
       Climates of New Zealand
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 181.33333333333px">
       <div style="width: 181.33333333333px">

          </a>
         </div>
        </div>

          </a>
         </p>

          </a>

        </div>

          </a>
          in winter
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
      <li class="gallerybox" style="width: 182.66666666667px">
       <div style="width: 182.66666666667px">
        <div class="thumb" style="width: 180.66666666667px;">
         <div style="margin:0px auto;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scorching_Bay.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Scorching_Bay.jpg/271px-Scorching_Bay.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Scorching_Bay.jpg/407px-Scorching_Bay.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Scorching_Bay.jpg/542px-Scorching_Bay.jpg 2x" width="181"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="gallerytext">
         <p>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scorching_Bay" title="Scorching Bay">
           Scorching Bay
          </a>
          beach in summer
         </p>
        </div>
       </div>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      The table below lists climate normals for the warmest and coldest month in the six largest cities of New Zealand. The North Island cities are generally slightly warmer in February, but the South Island cities are warmest in January.
     </p>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">
       Biodiversity
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_of_New_Zealand" title="Biodiversity of New Zealand">
       Biodiversity of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TeTuatahianui.jpg">
        <img alt="Kiwi amongst sticks" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1325" data-file-width="994" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/TeTuatahianui.jpg/170px-TeTuatahianui.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/TeTuatahianui.jpg/255px-TeTuatahianui.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/TeTuatahianui.jpg/340px-TeTuatahianui.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TeTuatahianui.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The endemic flightless
        <a href="/wiki/Kiwi" title="Kiwi">
         kiwi
        </a>
        is a national icon.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geographic_isolation" title="Geographic isolation">
       geographic isolation
      </a>
      for 80 million years
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
       <a href="#cite_note-162">
        [155]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and island
      <a href="/wiki/Biogeography" title="Biogeography">
       biogeography
      </a>
      has influenced evolution of the country's species of
      <a href="/wiki/Fauna" title="Fauna">
       animals
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">
       fungi
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Flora" title="Flora">
       plants
      </a>
      . Physical isolation has not caused biological isolation, and this has resulted in a dynamic evolutionary ecology with examples of very distinctive plants and animals as well as populations of widespread species.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        [156]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        [157]
       </a>
      </sup>
      About 82% of New Zealand's indigenous
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vascular_plants" title="Vascular plants">
       vascular plants
      </a>
      are
      <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">
       endemic
      </a>
      , covering 1,944 species across 65
      <a href="/wiki/Genus" title="Genus">
       genera
      </a>
      and includes a single endemic
      <a href="/wiki/Family_(biology)" title="Family (biology)">
       family
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAQ_165-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FAQ-165">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZPCN_2006_166-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZPCN_2006-166">
        [159]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The number of fungi recorded from New Zealand, including lichen-forming species, is not known, nor is the proportion of those fungi which are endemic, but one estimate suggests there are about 2,300 species of lichen-forming fungi in New Zealand
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FAQ_165-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FAQ-165">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 40% of these are endemic.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The two main types of forest are those dominated by broadleaf trees with emergent
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Podocarp" title="Podocarp">
       podocarps
      </a>
      , or by
      <a href="/wiki/Nothofagus" title="Nothofagus">
       southern beech
      </a>
      in cooler climates.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
       <a href="#cite_note-168">
        [161]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The remaining vegetation types consist of grasslands, the majority of which are
      <a href="/wiki/Tussock_grasslands_of_New_Zealand" title="Tussock grasslands of New Zealand">
       tussock
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        [162]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Before the arrival of humans an estimated 80% of the land was covered in forest, with only
      <a href="/wiki/Tree_line" title="Tree line">
       high alpine
      </a>
      , wet, infertile and volcanic areas without trees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        [163]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Massive
      <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_New_Zealand" title="Deforestation in New Zealand">
       deforestation
      </a>
      occurred after humans arrived, with around half the forest cover lost to fire after Polynesian settlement.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        [164]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Much of the remaining forest fell after European settlement, being logged or cleared to make room for pastoral farming, leaving forest occupying only 23% of the land.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Megalapteryx.png">
        <img alt="Restored drawing from feathers and mummified remains." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3240" data-file-width="2266" height="243" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d7/Megalapteryx.png/170px-Megalapteryx.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d7/Megalapteryx.png/255px-Megalapteryx.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d7/Megalapteryx.png/340px-Megalapteryx.png 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Megalapteryx.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The extinct
        <a href="/wiki/Moa" title="Moa">
         moa
        </a>
        (
        <i>
         Megalapteryx didinus
        </i>
        ).
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The forests were dominated by
      <a href="/wiki/Birds_of_New_Zealand" title="Birds of New Zealand">
       birds
      </a>
      , and the lack of mammalian predators led to some like the
      <a href="/wiki/Kiwi" title="Kiwi">
       kiwi
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Kakapo" title="Kakapo">
       kakapo
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Weka" title="Weka">
       weka
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Takah%C4%93" title="Takahē">
       takahē
      </a>
      evolving
      <a href="/wiki/Flightless_bird" title="Flightless bird">
       flightlessness
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
       <a href="#cite_note-173">
        [166]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The arrival of humans, associated changes to habitat, and the introduction of
      <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_rat" title="Polynesian rat">
       rats
      </a>
      , ferrets and other mammals led to the
      <a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">
       extinction
      </a>
      of many bird species, including
      <a href="/wiki/Megafauna" title="Megafauna">
       large birds
      </a>
      like the
      <a href="/wiki/Moa" title="Moa">
       moa
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Haast%27s_eagle" title="Haast's eagle">
       Haast's eagle
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-extinction_174-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-extinction-174">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
       <a href="#cite_note-175">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other indigenous animals are represented by reptiles (
      <a href="/wiki/Tuatara" title="Tuatara">
       tuataras
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Skink" title="Skink">
       skinks
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Gecko" title="Gecko">
       geckos
      </a>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Leiopelmatidae" title="Leiopelmatidae">
       frogs
      </a>
      , spiders (
      <a href="/wiki/Katipo" title="Katipo">
       katipo
      </a>
      ), insects (
      <a href="/wiki/Weta" title="Weta">
       weta
      </a>
      ) and snails.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_wren" title="New Zealand wren">
       wrens
      </a>
      and tuatara, are so unique that they have been called
      <a href="/wiki/Living_fossil" title="Living fossil">
       living fossils
      </a>
      . Three species of bats (
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_greater_short-tailed_bat" title="New Zealand greater short-tailed bat">
       one
      </a>
      since extinct) were the only sign of native land mammals in New Zealand until the 2006 discovery of bones from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SB_mammal" title="SB mammal">
       a unique, mouse-sized land mammal
      </a>
      at least 16 million years old.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
       <a href="#cite_note-180">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Marine mammals however are abundant, with almost half the world's
      <a href="/wiki/Cetacea" title="Cetacea">
       cetaceans
      </a>
      (whales, dolphins, and
      <a href="/wiki/Porpoise" title="Porpoise">
       porpoises
      </a>
      ) and large numbers of
      <a href="/wiki/Fur_seal" title="Fur seal">
       fur seals
      </a>
      reported in New Zealand waters.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
       <a href="#cite_note-181">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Many seabirds breed in New Zealand, a third of them unique to the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
       <a href="#cite_note-182">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_New_Zealand#Sphenisciformes" title="List of birds of New Zealand">
       penguin
      </a>
      species are found in New Zealand than in any other country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
       <a href="#cite_note-183">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Since human arrival almost half of the country's vertebrate species have become extinct, including at least fifty-one birds, three frogs, three lizards, one freshwater fish, and one bat. Others are endangered or have had their range severely reduced.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-extinction_174-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-extinction-174">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, New Zealand conservationists have pioneered several methods to help threatened wildlife recover, including island sanctuaries, pest control, wildlife translocation, fostering, and ecological
      <a href="/wiki/Island_restoration" title="Island restoration">
       restoration of islands
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Ecological_island" title="Ecological island">
       other selected areas
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
       <a href="#cite_note-184">
        [177]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
       <a href="#cite_note-185">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
       <a href="#cite_note-186">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
       <a href="#cite_note-187">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
       Economy
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_New_Zealand" title="Economy of New Zealand">
       Economy of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_New_Zealand" title="List of companies of New Zealand">
       List of companies of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg">
        <img alt="Boats docked in blue-green water. Plate glass skyscrapers rising up in the background." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3019" data-file-width="4568" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg/220px-Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg/330px-Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg/440px-Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Auckland_Waterfrt.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Auckland_waterfront" title="Auckland waterfront">
         Waterfront
        </a>
        along
        <a href="/wiki/Auckland_CBD" title="Auckland CBD">
         Auckland CBD
        </a>
        , a major hub of economic activity.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      New Zealand has a high-income
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Developed_economy#IMF_advanced_economies" title="Developed economy">
       advanced economy
      </a>
      with a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nominal_value" title="Nominal value">
       nominal
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">
       gross domestic product
      </a>
      (GDP) per capita of
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">
       US$
      </a>
      36,254.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-imf2_12-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-imf2-12">
        [8]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The currency is the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_dollar" title="New Zealand dollar">
       New Zealand dollar
      </a>
      , informally known as the "Kiwi dollar"; it also circulates in the Cook Islands (see
      <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands_dollar" title="Cook Islands dollar">
       Cook Islands dollar
      </a>
      ), Niue, Tokelau, and the
      <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">
       Pitcairn Islands
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
       <a href="#cite_note-188">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand was ranked sixth in the 2013
      <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">
       Human Development Index
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
       <a href="#cite_note-189">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      fourth in
      <a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">
       The Heritage Foundation
      </a>
      's 2012
      <a href="/wiki/Index_of_Economic_Freedom" title="Index of Economic Freedom">
       Index of Economic Freedom
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
       <a href="#cite_note-190">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 13th in
      <a href="/wiki/INSEAD" title="INSEAD">
       INSEAD
      </a>
      's 2012
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index_(Cornell_University,_INSEAD_and_WIPO)" title="Global Innovation Index (Cornell University, INSEAD and WIPO)">
       Global Innovation Index
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
       <a href="#cite_note-191">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Historically, extractive industries have contributed strongly to New Zealand's economy, focussing at different times on sealing, whaling,
      <a href="/wiki/Phormium" title="Phormium">
       flax
      </a>
      , gold,
      <a href="/wiki/Kauri_gum" title="Kauri gum">
       kauri gum
      </a>
      , and native timber.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RWT_export_evolution_192-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RWT_export_evolution-192">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With
      <a href="/wiki/Dunedin_(ship)" title="Dunedin (ship)">
       the development of refrigerated shipping
      </a>
      in the 1880s meat and dairy products were exported to Britain, a trade which provided the basis for strong economic growth in New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
       <a href="#cite_note-193">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
      High demand for agricultural products from the United Kingdom and the United States helped New Zealanders achieve higher living standards than both Australia and Western Europe in the 1950s and 1960s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
       <a href="#cite_note-194">
        [187]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1973, New Zealand's export market was reduced when the United Kingdom joined the European Community
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
       <a href="#cite_note-195">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and other compounding factors, such as the
      <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">
       1973 oil
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/1979_energy_crisis" title="1979 energy crisis">
       1979 energy crisis
      </a>
      , led to a severe
      <a href="/wiki/Depression_(economics)" title="Depression (economics)">
       economic depression
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
       <a href="#cite_note-196">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Living standards in New Zealand fell behind those of Australia and Western Europe, and by 1982 New Zealand had the lowest per-capita income of all the developed nations surveyed by
      <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">
       the World Bank
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
       <a href="#cite_note-197">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since 1984, successive governments engaged in major
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Macroeconomic" title="Macroeconomic">
       macroeconomic
      </a>
      restructuring (known first as
      <a href="/wiki/Rogernomics" title="Rogernomics">
       Rogernomics
      </a>
      and then
      <a href="/wiki/Ruthanasia" title="Ruthanasia">
       Ruthanasia
      </a>
      ), rapidly transforming New Zealand from a highly
      <a href="/wiki/Protectionism" title="Protectionism">
       protectionist
      </a>
      economy to a liberalised
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Free-trade" title="Free-trade">
       free-trade
      </a>
      economy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liberalisation_198-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Liberalisation-198">
        [191]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
       <a href="#cite_note-199">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MilfordSound.jpg">
        <img alt="Blue water against a backdrop of snow-capped mountains" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1364" data-file-width="2048" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/MilfordSound.jpg/220px-MilfordSound.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/MilfordSound.jpg/330px-MilfordSound.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/MilfordSound.jpg/440px-MilfordSound.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MilfordSound.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Milford_Sound" title="Milford Sound">
         Milford Sound
        </a>
        is one of New Zealand's most famous tourist destinations.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stuff.co.nz_200-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-stuff.co.nz-200">
          [193]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Unemployment peaked above 10% in 1991 and 1992,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
       <a href="#cite_note-201">
        [194]
       </a>
      </sup>
      following the
      <a href="/wiki/Black_Monday_(1987)" title="Black Monday (1987)">
       1987 share market crash
      </a>
      , but eventually fell to a record low of 3.4% in 2007 (ranking fifth from twenty-seven comparable OECD nations).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
       <a href="#cite_note-202">
        [195]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the
      <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932008" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2008">
       global financial crisis
      </a>
      that followed had a major impact on New Zealand, with the GDP shrinking for five consecutive quarters, the longest recession in over thirty years,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
       <a href="#cite_note-203">
        [196]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
       <a href="#cite_note-204">
        [197]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and unemployment rising back to 7% in late 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
       <a href="#cite_note-205">
        [198]
       </a>
      </sup>
      At May 2012, the general unemployment rate was around 6.7%, while the unemployment rate for youth aged 15 to 21 was 13.6%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
       <a href="#cite_note-206">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the September 2014 quarter, unemployment was 5.4%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hlfs_september_2014_207-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hlfs_september_2014-207">
        [200]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand has experienced a series of "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">
       brain drains
      </a>
      " since the 1970s
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
       <a href="#cite_note-208">
        [201]
       </a>
      </sup>
      that still continue today.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
       <a href="#cite_note-209">
        [202]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Nearly one quarter of highly skilled workers live overseas, mostly in Australia and Britain, which is the largest proportion from any developed nation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
       <a href="#cite_note-210">
        [203]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In recent years, however, a "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_gain" title="Brain gain">
       brain gain
      </a>
      " has brought in educated professionals from Europe and less developed countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
       <a href="#cite_note-211">
        [204]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBain200644_212-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBain200644-212">
        [205]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Trade">
       Trade
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      New Zealand is heavily dependent on international trade,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
       <a href="#cite_note-213">
        [206]
       </a>
      </sup>
      particularly in
      <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_New_Zealand" title="Agriculture in New Zealand">
       agricultural
      </a>
      products.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
       <a href="#cite_note-214">
        [207]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Exports account for 24% of its output,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      making New Zealand vulnerable to international commodity prices and global
      <a href="/wiki/Recession" title="Recession">
       economic slowdowns
      </a>
      . Food products made up 55% of the value of all the country's exports in 2014; wood was the second largest earner (7%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
       <a href="#cite_note-215">
        [208]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its major export partners are Australia, United States, Japan, China, and the United Kingdom.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On 7 April 2008, New Zealand and China signed the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand%E2%80%93China_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="New Zealand–China Free Trade Agreement">
       New Zealand–China Free Trade Agreement
      </a>
      , the first such agreement China has signed with a developed country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
       <a href="#cite_note-216">
        [209]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
       <a href="#cite_note-217">
        [210]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The service sector is the largest sector in the economy, followed by manufacturing and construction and then farming and raw material extraction.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_New_Zealand" title="Tourism in New Zealand">
       Tourism
      </a>
      plays a significant role in New Zealand's economy, contributing $15.0 billion to New Zealand’s total GDP and supporting 9.6% of the total workforce in 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TourismStats_218-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TourismStats-218">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
      International visitors to New Zealand increased by 3.1% in the year to October 2010
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
       <a href="#cite_note-219">
        [212]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and are expected to increase at a rate of 2.5% annually up to 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TourismStats_218-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TourismStats-218">
        [211]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In 1984 New Zealand deregulated its agricultural economy by phasing out
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Farm_subsidies" title="Farm subsidies">
       farm subsidies
      </a>
      over a three-year period.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220">
       <a href="#cite_note-220">
        [213]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221">
       <a href="#cite_note-221">
        [214]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg">
        <img alt="A Romney ewe with her two lambs" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="843" data-file-width="1280" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg/220px-Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg/330px-Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg/440px-Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Romney_Ewe_and_Lamb.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Wool has historically been one of New Zealand's major exports.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Wool was New Zealand’s major agricultural export during the late 19th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RWT_export_evolution_192-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RWT_export_evolution-192">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even as late as the 1960s it made up over a third of all export revenues,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RWT_export_evolution_192-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-RWT_export_evolution-192">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but since then its price has steadily dropped relative to other commodities
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222">
       <a href="#cite_note-222">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and wool is no longer profitable for many farmers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223">
       <a href="#cite_note-223">
        [216]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In contrast dairy farming increased, with the number of dairy cows doubling between 1990 and 2007,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
       <a href="#cite_note-224">
        [217]
       </a>
      </sup>
      to become New Zealand's largest export earner.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225">
       <a href="#cite_note-225">
        [218]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the year to June 2009, dairy products accounted for 21% ($9.1 billion) of total merchandise exports,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
       <a href="#cite_note-226">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the country's largest company,
      <a href="/wiki/Fonterra" title="Fonterra">
       Fonterra
      </a>
      , controls almost one-third of the international dairy trade.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        [220]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other agricultural exports in 2009 were meat 13.2%, wool 6.3%, fruit 3.5% and fishing 3.3%.
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_wine" title="New Zealand wine">
       New Zealand's wine
      </a>
      industry has followed a similar trend to dairy, the number of vineyards doubling over the same period,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        [221]
       </a>
      </sup>
      overtaking wool exports for the first time in 2007.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
       <a href="#cite_note-229">
        [222]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
       <a href="#cite_note-230">
        [223]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Infrastructure">
       Infrastructure
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In 2014,
      <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_in_New_Zealand" title="Renewable energy in New Zealand">
       renewable energy
      </a>
      generated 39.5% of
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_New_Zealand" title="Energy in New Zealand">
       New Zealand's gross energy
      </a>
      supply, primarily
      <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectric_power_in_New_Zealand" title="Hydroelectric power in New Zealand">
       hydroelectric power
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Geothermal_power_in_New_Zealand" title="Geothermal power in New Zealand">
       geothermal power
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Energy2015_231-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Energy2015-231">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The provision of
      <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_New_Zealand" title="Water supply and sanitation in New Zealand">
       water supply and sanitation
      </a>
      is generally of good quality. Regional authorities provide water abstraction, treatment and distribution infrastructure to most developed areas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_New_Zealand" title="Transport in New Zealand">
       New Zealand's transport
      </a>
      network comprises 93,805 kilometres (58,288 mi) of roads, including 199 kilometres (124 mi) of motorways,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
       <a href="#cite_note-234">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 4,128 kilometres (2,565 mi) of railway lines.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most major cities and towns are linked by bus services, although the private car is the predominant mode of transport.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
       <a href="#cite_note-235">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_New_Zealand" title="Rail transport in New Zealand">
       railways
      </a>
      were privatised in 1993, but were re-nationalised by the government in stages between 2004 and 2008. The state-owned enterprise
      <a href="/wiki/KiwiRail" title="KiwiRail">
       KiwiRail
      </a>
      now operates the railways, with the exception of Auckland commuter services which are operated by
      <a href="/wiki/Transdev_Auckland" title="Transdev Auckland">
       Transdev
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Railways run the length of the country, although most lines now carry freight rather than passengers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
       <a href="#cite_note-237">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most international visitors arrive via air
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
       <a href="#cite_note-238">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and New Zealand has
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_New_Zealand" title="List of airports in New Zealand">
       six international airports
      </a>
      , but currently
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      only the
      <a href="/wiki/Auckland_Airport" title="Auckland Airport">
       Auckland
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Christchurch_International_Airport" title="Christchurch International Airport">
       Christchurch airports
      </a>
      connect directly with countries other than Australia or Fiji.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Post_Office" title="New Zealand Post Office">
       New Zealand Post Office
      </a>
      had a monopoly over telecommunications until 1987 when
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telecom_New_Zealand" title="Telecom New Zealand">
       Telecom New Zealand
      </a>
      was formed, initially as a state-owned enterprise and then
      <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">
       privatised
      </a>
      in 1990.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Telecom was
      <a href="/wiki/Rebranding" title="Rebranding">
       rebranded
      </a>
      as
      <a href="/wiki/Spark_New_Zealand" title="Spark New Zealand">
       Spark New Zealand
      </a>
      in 2014.
      <a href="/wiki/Chorus_Limited" title="Chorus Limited">
       Chorus
      </a>
      , which was split from Telecom in 2011, still owns the majority of the telecommunications infrastructure, but competition from other providers has increased. The United Nations
      <a href="/wiki/International_Telecommunication_Union" title="International Telecommunication Union">
       International Telecommunication Union
      </a>
      ranks New Zealand 12th in the development of information and communications infrastructure, having moved up four places between 2008 and 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
       <a href="#cite_note-241">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Demography">
       Demography
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_New_Zealand" title="Demographics of New Zealand">
       Demographics of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png">
        <img alt="Graph with a New Zealand population scale ranging from 0 to almost 7 million on the y axis and the years from 1850 to around 2070 on the x axis. A black line starts at about 100,000 in 1858 and increases steadily to about 4.1 million in 2006. Seven separate red lines then project out from the black line ending in values ranging from roughly 4.5 to 6.5 million in the year 2061; two lines are slightly thicker than the rest." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="580" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png/300px-New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png/450px-New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ec/New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png 2x" width="300"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_population_over_time_-_small.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        New Zealand's historical population (black) and projected growth (red).
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      As of June 2016, the population of New Zealand is estimated at 4.69 million and is increasing at a rate of approximately 2.1% per year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-populationestimate_242-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-populationestimate-242">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand is a predominantly urban country, with 73.0% of the population living in the seventeen main urban areas (i.e. population 30,000 or greater) and 53.7% living in the four largest cities of
      <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">
       Auckland
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Christchurch" title="Christchurch">
       Christchurch
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">
       Wellington
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Hamilton,_New_Zealand" title="Hamilton, New Zealand">
       Hamilton
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Urban_243-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Urban-243">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand cities generally rank highly on international livability measures. For instance, in 2010
      <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">
       Auckland
      </a>
      was ranked the world's 4th most
      <a href="/wiki/World%27s_most_liveable_cities" title="World's most liveable cities">
       liveable city
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">
       Wellington
      </a>
      the 12th by the
      <a href="/wiki/Mercer_(consulting_firm)" title="Mercer (consulting firm)">
       Mercer
      </a>
      Quality of Life Survey.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mercer_244-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mercer-244">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Life expectancy for New Zealanders in 2012 was 84 years for females, and 80.2 years for males.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
       <a href="#cite_note-245">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Life expectancy at birth is forecast to increase from 80 years to 85 years in 2050 and infant mortality is expected to decline.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNtwspop_246-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UNtwspop-246">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fertility_rate" title="Fertility rate">
       fertility rate
      </a>
      of 2.1 is relatively high for a developed country, and natural births account for a significant proportion of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Replacement_fertility_rate" title="Replacement fertility rate">
       population growth
      </a>
      . Consequently, the country has a young population compared to most industrialized nations, with 20% of New Zealanders being 14 years old or younger.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By 2050 the population is forecast to reach 5.3 million, the median age to rise from 36 years to 43 years and the percentage of people 60 years of age and older to rise from 18% to 29%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UNtwspop_246-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-UNtwspop-246">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Despite the high life expectancy, mortality from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heart_disease" title="Heart disease">
       heart disease
      </a>
      is higher in New Zealand than it is in various other developed Western countries such as
      <a href="/wiki/Australia" title="Australia">
       Australia
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
       United Kingdom
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">
       Canada
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
       <a href="#cite_note-247">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <br/>
     </p>
     <table class="navbox">
      <tr>
       <th class="navbox-title" colspan="10">
        <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">

            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-talk">

            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="nv-edit">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_in_New_Zealand&amp;action=edit">
            <abbr title="Edit this template">
             e
            </abbr>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </div>
        <div style="height:2.6em;line-height:1.3em;">
         <span style="font-size:110%;">
          Largest urban areas in New Zealand
         </span>
         <br/>
         <span style="font-weight:normal;">
          <a href="/wiki/Statistics_New_Zealand" title="Statistics New Zealand">
           Statistics New Zealand
          </a>
          June 2016 estimate
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_population_data_248-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-NZ_population_data-248">
            [241]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </span>
        </div>
       </th>
      </tr>

        </a>
       </th>
       <th>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ranked_list_of_New_Zealand_urban_areas" title="Ranked list of New Zealand urban areas">
         Pop.
        </a>
       </th>
       <th>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ranked_list_of_New_Zealand_urban_areas" title="Ranked list of New Zealand urban areas">
         Rank
        </a>
       </th>
       <th>
        <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_New_Zealand" title="List of cities in New Zealand">

        </a>
       </th>
       <th>
        <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_New_Zealand" title="Regions of New Zealand">
         Region
        </a>
       </th>
       <th>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ranked_list_of_New_Zealand_urban_areas" title="Ranked list of New Zealand urban areas">
         Pop.
        </a>
       </th>
       <th>
       </th>
      </tr>

        <br/>

        <br/>

        </a>
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Wellington" title="Wellington">
         Wellington
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
        1
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/Auckland" title="Auckland">
         Auckland
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/Auckland_Region" title="Auckland Region">
         Auckland
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        1,495,000
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">
        11
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a href="/wiki/New_Plymouth" title="New Plymouth">
         New Plymouth
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:left;">
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Taranaki_Region" title="Taranaki Region">
         Taranaki
        </a>
       </td>
       <td style="text-align:right;">
        56,800
       </td>
       <td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Christchurch_Central,_Christchurch,_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Christchurch">
         <img alt="Christchurch" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1800" data-file-width="2700" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Christchurch_Central%2C_Christchurch%2C_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg/120px-Christchurch_Central%2C_Christchurch%2C_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Christchurch_Central%2C_Christchurch%2C_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg/180px-Christchurch_Central%2C_Christchurch%2C_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Christchurch_Central%2C_Christchurch%2C_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg/240px-Christchurch_Central%2C_Christchurch%2C_New_Zealand_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
        </a>
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Christchurch" title="Christchurch">
         Christchurch
        </a>
        <br/>
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg" title="Hamilton">
         <img alt="Hamilton" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2528" data-file-width="3581" height="85" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg/120px-HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg/180px-HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg/240px-HamiltonNZfromUni.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
        </a>
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Hamilton,_New_Zealand" title="Hamilton, New Zealand">
         Hamilton
        </a>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
