     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicity_and_immigration">
       Ethnicity and immigration
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealanders" title="New Zealanders">
       New Zealanders
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_New_Zealand" title="Immigration to New Zealand">
       Immigration to New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:402px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="1357" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG/400px-NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG/600px-NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG/800px-NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG 2x" width="400"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NZ_residency_by_country_of_nationality_2004-5FY.PNG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Acquisition of New Zealand residency by citizenship, 2004/05 (fy).
        <br/>
        Source:
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Department_of_Labour" title="New Zealand Department of Labour">
         New Zealand Department of Labour
        </a>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
         <a href="#cite_note-249">
          [242]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In the 2013 census, 74.0% of New Zealand residents identified ethnically as European, and 14.9% as Māori. Other major ethnic groups include
      <a href="/wiki/Asian_people" title="Asian people">
       Asian
      </a>
      (11.8%) and Pacific peoples (7.4%), of which two-thirds live in the Auckland region.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnic_groups_in_NZ_250-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ethnic_groups_in_NZ-250">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        [n 8]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The population has become more diverse in recent decades: in 1961, the census reported that the population of New Zealand was 92% European and 7% Māori, with Asian and Pacific minorities sharing the remaining 1%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
       <a href="#cite_note-252">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      While the
      <a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">
       demonym
      </a>
      for a New Zealand citizen is New Zealander, the informal "
      <a href="/wiki/Kiwi_(people)" title="Kiwi (people)">
       Kiwi
      </a>
      " is commonly used both internationally
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
       <a href="#cite_note-253">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and by locals.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Māori loanword
      <a href="/wiki/P%C4%81keh%C4%81" title="Pākehā">
       Pākehā
      </a>
      has been used to refer to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Zealand_European" title="New Zealand European">
       New Zealanders of European descent
      </a>
      , although others reject this appellation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The word Pākehā today is increasingly used to refer to all non-Polynesian New Zealanders.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pakeha_257-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Pakeha-257">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Māori were the first people to reach New Zealand, followed by the early European settlers. Following colonisation, immigrants were predominantly from Britain, Ireland and Australia because of restrictive policies similar to the
      <a href="/wiki/White_Australia_policy" title="White Australia policy">
       white Australian policies
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
       <a href="#cite_note-258">
        [250]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There was also significant Dutch,
      <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">
       Dalmatian
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dalmatians_259-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Dalmatians-259">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Italian, and German immigration, together with indirect European immigration through Australia, North America, South America and South Africa.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peoples_260-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Peoples-260">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Following the
      <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
       Great Depression
      </a>
      policies were relaxed and migrant diversity increased. In 2009–10, an annual target of 45,000–50,000 permanent residence approvals was set by the New Zealand Immigration Service—more than one new migrant for every 100 New Zealand residents.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Recent_immigration_261-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Recent_immigration-261">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Just over 25% of New Zealand's population was born overseas, with the majority (52%) living in the Auckland region. The United Kingdom remains the largest source of New Zealand's overseas population, with a quarter of all overseas-born New Zealanders born there; other major sources of New Zealand's overseas-born population are China, India, Australia, South Africa, Fiji and Samoa.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
       <a href="#cite_note-262">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The number of fee-paying
      <a href="/wiki/International_student" title="International student">
       international students
      </a>
      increased sharply in the late 1990s, with more than 20,000 studying in public
      <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">
       tertiary institutions
      </a>
      in 2002.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
       <a href="#cite_note-263">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Language">
       Language
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:TeReoMaori2013.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3759" data-file-width="5000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/TeReoMaori2013.png/220px-TeReoMaori2013.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/TeReoMaori2013.png/330px-TeReoMaori2013.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/TeReoMaori2013.png/440px-TeReoMaori2013.png 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:TeReoMaori2013.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Speakers of Māori according to the 2013 census.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
         <a href="#cite_note-264">
          [256]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #fef0d9; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         Less than 5%
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #fdd8a4; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         More than 5%
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #fcb779; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         More than 10%
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #fc8d59; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         More than 20%
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #eb603f; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         More than 30%
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #d33121; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         More than 40%
        </div>
        <div class="legend">
         <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #a50c0c; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
         </span>
         More than 50%
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_New_Zealand" title="Languages of New Zealand">
       Languages of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      English is the predominant language in New Zealand, spoken by 96.1% of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpokenLanguage_6-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SpokenLanguage-6">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_English" title="New Zealand English">
       New Zealand English
      </a>
      is similar to
      <a href="/wiki/Australian_English" title="Australian English">
       Australian English
      </a>
      and many speakers from the Northern Hemisphere are unable to tell the
      <a href="/wiki/Accent_(sociolinguistics)" title="Accent (sociolinguistics)">
       accents
      </a>
      apart.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHayMaclaganGordon200814_265-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHayMaclaganGordon200814-265">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The most prominent differences between the New Zealand English dialect and other English dialects are the shifts in the short front vowels: the short-"i" sound (as in "kit") has centralised towards the
      <a href="/wiki/Schwa" title="Schwa">
       schwa
      </a>
      sound (the "a" in "comma" and "about"); the short-"e" sound (as in "dress") has moved towards the short-"i" sound; and the short-"a" sound (as in "trap") has moved to the short-"e" sound.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      After the Second World War, Māori were discouraged from speaking their own language (
      <i>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Te_reo_M%C4%81ori" title="Te reo Māori">
        te reo Māori
       </a>
      </i>
      ) in schools and workplaces and it existed as a community language only in a few remote areas.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maori_language_267-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Maori_language-267">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It has recently undergone a process of revitalisation,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      being declared one of New Zealand's official languages in 1987,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maori_language_act_269-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Maori_language_act-269">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and is spoken by 3.7% of the population.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpokenLanguage_6-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-SpokenLanguage-6">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
       <a href="#cite_note-271">
        [n 9]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are now Māori language immersion schools and two television channels that broadcast predominantly in Māori.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_dual_place_names_in_New_Zealand" title="List of dual place names in New Zealand">
       Many places
      </a>
      have both their Māori and English names officially recognised.
     </p>
     <p>
      As recorded in the 2013 census,
      <a href="/wiki/Samoan_language" title="Samoan language">
       Samoan
      </a>
      is the most widely spoken non-official language (2.2%),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [n 10]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed by Hindi (1.7%), "Northern Chinese" (including
      <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">
       Mandarin
      </a>
      , 1.3%) and French (1.2%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpokenLanguage_6-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-SpokenLanguage-6">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      About 20,000 people use
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Sign_Language" title="New Zealand Sign Language">
       New Zealand Sign Language
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
       <a href="#cite_note-274">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It was declared one of New Zealand's official languages in 2006.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
       <a href="#cite_note-275">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">
       Religion
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_New_Zealand" title="Religion in New Zealand">
       Religion in New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg">
        <img alt="Simple white building with two red domed towers" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2164" data-file-width="1624" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg/170px-Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg/255px-Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg/340px-Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ratana_Church_Raetihi.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/R%C4%81tana" title="Rātana">
         Rātana
        </a>
        church near
        <a href="/wiki/Raetihi" title="Raetihi">
         Raetihi
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_New_Zealand" title="Christianity in New Zealand">
       Christianity
      </a>
      is the predominant religion in New Zealand, although its society is among the most
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Secular" title="Secular">
       secular
      </a>
      in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
       <a href="#cite_note-276">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 2013 census, 55.0% of the population identified with one or more religions, including 49.0% identifying as Christians. Another 41.9% indicated that they had no religion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
       <a href="#cite_note-277">
        [n 11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013religiouscommentary_278-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2013religiouscommentary-278">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The main Christian denominations are
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_New_Zealand" title="Roman Catholicism in New Zealand">
       Roman Catholicism
      </a>
      (12.6%),
      <a href="/wiki/Anglican_Church_in_Aotearoa,_New_Zealand_and_Polynesia" title="Anglican Church in Aotearoa, New Zealand and Polynesia">
       Anglicanism
      </a>
      (11.8%),
      <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian_Church_of_Aotearoa_New_Zealand" title="Presbyterian Church of Aotearoa New Zealand">
       Presbyterianism
      </a>
      (8.5%) and "Christian not further defined" (i.e. people identifying as Christian but not stating the denomination, 5.5%).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013religiouscommentary_278-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-2013religiouscommentary-278">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Māori-based
      <a href="/wiki/Ringat%C5%AB" title="Ringatū">
       Ringatū
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/R%C4%81tana" title="Rātana">
       Rātana
      </a>
      religions (1.4%) are also Christian.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other significant minority religions include
      <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_New_Zealand" title="Hinduism in New Zealand">
       Hinduism
      </a>
      (2.3%),
      <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">
       Buddhism
      </a>
      (1.5%) and
      <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_New_Zealand" title="Islam in New Zealand">
       Islam
      </a>
      (1.2%). The indigenous Māori Christians tend to be associated with the Anglican and Catholic churches, while
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander" title="Pacific Islander">
       Pacific people
      </a>
      tend to be Presbyterian, Methodist, Catholic and
      <a href="/wiki/Latter_Day_Saint_movement" title="Latter Day Saint movement">
       Latter-day Saint
      </a>
      adherents.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2013religiouscommentary_278-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-2013religiouscommentary-278">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
       Education
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Education_in_New_Zealand" title="Education in New Zealand">
       Education in New Zealand
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_universities_in_New_Zealand" title="List of universities in New Zealand">
       List of universities in New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Primary and secondary schooling is compulsory for children aged 6 to 16, with the majority attending from the age of 5.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Education_Stats_280-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Education_Stats-280">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are 13 school years and attending
      <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">
       state (public) schools
      </a>
      is free to New Zealand citizens and permanent residents from a person's 5th birthday to the end of the calendar year following their 19th birthday.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281">
       <a href="#cite_note-281">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand has an adult literacy rate of 99%,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_144-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-CIA-144">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and over half of the population aged 15 to 29 hold a tertiary qualification.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Education_Stats_280-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Education_Stats-280">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282">
       <a href="#cite_note-282">
        [n 12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are five types of government-owned tertiary institutions: universities, colleges of education,
      <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_technology#New_Zealand" title="Institute of technology">
       polytechnics
      </a>
      , specialist colleges, and
      <a href="/wiki/W%C4%81nanga" title="Wānanga">
       wānanga
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EducationAct1989_283-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EducationAct1989-283">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      in addition to private training establishments.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZQA_284-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZQA-284">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the adult population 14.2% have a
      <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">
       bachelor's degree
      </a>
      or higher, 30.4% have some form of secondary qualification as their highest qualification and 22.4% have no formal qualification.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TertiaryEdStats_285-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TertiaryEdStats-285">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The OECD's
      <a href="/wiki/Programme_for_International_Student_Assessment" title="Programme for International Student Assessment">
       Programme for International Student Assessment
      </a>
      ranks New Zealand's education system as the 7th best in the world, with students performing exceptionally well in reading, mathematics and science.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286">
       <a href="#cite_note-286">
        [274]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">
       Culture
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_New_Zealand" title="Culture of New Zealand">
       Culture of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KupeWheke.jpg">
        <img alt="Tall wooden carving showing Kupe above two tentacled sea creatures" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1570" data-file-width="389" height="565" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/KupeWheke.jpg/140px-KupeWheke.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/KupeWheke.jpg/210px-KupeWheke.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/KupeWheke.jpg/280px-KupeWheke.jpg 2x" width="140"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KupeWheke.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Late twentieth-century house-post depicting the navigator
        <a href="/wiki/Kupe" title="Kupe">
         Kupe
        </a>
        fighting two sea creatures.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Early Māori adapted the tropically based east
      <a href="/wiki/Polynesian_culture" title="Polynesian culture">
       Polynesian culture
      </a>
      in line with the challenges associated with a larger and more diverse environment, eventually developing their own distinctive culture. Social organisation was largely communal with families (whanau), sub-tribes (hapu) and tribes (iwi) ruled by a chief (rangatira) whose position was subject to the community's approval.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007398_287-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007398-287">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The British and Irish immigrants brought aspects of their own culture to New Zealand and also influenced Māori culture,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288">
       <a href="#cite_note-288">
        [276]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289">
       <a href="#cite_note-289">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      particularly with the introduction of Christianity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290">
       <a href="#cite_note-290">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, Māori still regard their allegiance to tribal groups as a vital part of
      <a href="/wiki/Identity_(social_science)" title="Identity (social science)">
       their identity
      </a>
      , and Māori kinship roles resemble
      <a href="/wiki/Hawaiian_kinship" title="Hawaiian kinship">
       those of other Polynesian peoples
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291">
       <a href="#cite_note-291">
        [279]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More recently
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_States" title="Culture of the United States">
       American
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Australia" title="Culture of Australia">
       Australian
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Asia" title="Culture of Asia">
       Asian
      </a>
      and other
      <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Europe" title="Culture of Europe">
       European cultures
      </a>
      have exerted influence on New Zealand. Non-Māori Polynesian cultures are also apparent, with
      <a href="/wiki/Pasifika_Festival" title="Pasifika Festival">
       Pasifika
      </a>
      , the world's largest Polynesian festival, now an annual event in Auckland.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish,_1909_(4836053716).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2515" data-file-width="3439" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish%2C_1909_%284836053716%29.jpg/220px-Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish%2C_1909_%284836053716%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish%2C_1909_%284836053716%29.jpg/330px-Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish%2C_1909_%284836053716%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish%2C_1909_%284836053716%29.jpg/440px-Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish%2C_1909_%284836053716%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Men_at_their_camp_site_displaying_a_catch_of_rabbits_and_fish,_1909_(4836053716).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Men at their camp site displaying a catch of rabbits and fish, 1909.
        <a href="/wiki/European_New_Zealanders" title="European New Zealanders">
         European settlers
        </a>
        , with their rustic lifestyle, developed a rugged and unassuming national identity.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007400_292-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007400-292">
          [280]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The largely rural life in early New Zealand led to the image of New Zealanders being rugged, industrious problem solvers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007400_292-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007400-292">
        [280]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Modesty was expected and enforced through the "
      <a href="/wiki/Tall_poppy_syndrome" title="Tall poppy syndrome">
       tall poppy syndrome
      </a>
      ", where high achievers received harsh criticism.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007399_293-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKennedy2007399-293">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      At the time New Zealand was not known as an intellectual country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        [282]
       </a>
      </sup>
      From the early 20th century until the late 1960s Māori culture was suppressed by the attempted assimilation of Māori into British New Zealanders.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maori_language_267-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Maori_language-267">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the 1960s, as higher education became more available and
      <a href="/wiki/Urbanization" title="Urbanization">
       cities expanded
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        [283]
       </a>
      </sup>
      urban culture began to dominate.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even though the majority of the population now lives in cities, much of New Zealand's art, literature, film and humour has rural themes. From around the middle of the 20th century, many cultural icons called
      <a href="/wiki/Kiwiana" title="Kiwiana">
       Kiwiana
      </a>
      , started to emerge that now help to define what it means to be a New Zealander; such as the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silver_fern" title="Silver fern">
       silver fern
      </a>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Paua" title="Paua">
       paua shell
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Art">
       Art
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_art" title="New Zealand art">
       New Zealand art
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      As part of the resurgence of Māori culture, the traditional crafts of carving and weaving are now more widely practised and Māori artists are increasing in number and influence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Creative_297-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Creative-297">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most Māori carvings feature human figures, generally with three fingers and either a natural-looking, detailed head or a grotesque head.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298">
       <a href="#cite_note-298">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Surface patterns consisting of spirals, ridges, notches and fish scales decorate most carvings.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299">
       <a href="#cite_note-299">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The pre-eminent Māori architecture consisted of carved meeting houses (
      <a href="/wiki/Wharenui" title="Wharenui">
       wharenui
      </a>
      ) decorated with symbolic carvings and illustrations. These buildings were originally designed to be constantly rebuilt, changing and adapting to different whims or needs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300">
       <a href="#cite_note-300">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Māori decorated the white wood of buildings, canoes and cenotaphs using red (a mixture of red
      <a href="/wiki/Ochre" title="Ochre">
       ochre
      </a>
      and shark fat) and black (made from soot) paint and painted pictures of birds, reptiles and other designs on cave walls.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301">
       <a href="#cite_note-301">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Māori tattoos (
      <a href="/wiki/T%C4%81_moko" title="Tā moko">
       moko
      </a>
      ) consisting of coloured soot mixed with gum were cut into the flesh with a bone chisel.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302">
       <a href="#cite_note-302">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since European arrival paintings and photographs have been dominated by landscapes, originally not as works of art but as factual portrayals of New Zealand.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-beginnings_303-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-beginnings-303">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Portraits of Māori were also common, with early painters often portraying them as "
      <a href="/wiki/Noble_savage" title="Noble savage">
       noble savages
      </a>
      ", exotic beauties or friendly natives.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-beginnings_303-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-beginnings-303">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The country's isolation delayed the influence of European artistic trends allowing local artists to developed their own distinctive style of
      <a href="/wiki/Regionalism_(art)" title="Regionalism (art)">
       regionalism
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304">
       <a href="#cite_note-304">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During the 1960s and 70s many artists combined traditional Māori and Western techniques, creating unique art forms.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305">
       <a href="#cite_note-305">
        [293]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand art and craft has gradually achieved an international audience, with exhibitions in the
      <a href="/wiki/Venice_Biennale" title="Venice Biennale">
       Venice Biennale
      </a>
      in 2001 and the "Paradise Now" exhibition in New York in 2004.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Creative_297-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Creative-297">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
       <a href="#cite_note-306">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hinepare.jpg">
        <img alt="Refer to caption" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="700" data-file-width="545" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Hinepare.jpg/170px-Hinepare.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Hinepare.jpg/255px-Hinepare.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Hinepare.jpg/340px-Hinepare.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hinepare.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Portrait of Hinepare of
        <a href="/wiki/Ng%C4%81ti_Kahungunu" title="Ngāti Kahungunu">
         Ngāti Kahungunu
        </a>
        by
        <a href="/wiki/Gottfried_Lindauer" title="Gottfried Lindauer">
         Gottfried Lindauer
        </a>
        , showing chin
        <a href="/wiki/T%C4%81_moko" title="Tā moko">
         moko
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Pounamu" title="Pounamu">
         pounamu
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Hei-tiki" title="Hei-tiki">
         hei-tiki
        </a>
        and woven cloak.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Māori cloaks are made of fine flax fibre and patterned with black, red and white triangles, diamonds and other geometric shapes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307">
       <a href="#cite_note-307">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Pounamu" title="Pounamu">
       Greenstone
      </a>
      was fashioned into earrings and necklaces, with the most well-known design being the
      <a href="/wiki/Hei-tiki" title="Hei-tiki">
       hei-tiki
      </a>
      , a distorted human figure sitting cross-legged with its head tilted to the side.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
       <a href="#cite_note-308">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Europeans brought English fashion etiquette to New Zealand, and until the 1950s most people dressed up for social occasions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
       <a href="#cite_note-309">
        [297]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Standards have since relaxed and New Zealand fashion has received a reputation for being casual, practical and lacklustre.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310">
       <a href="#cite_note-310">
        [298]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Economist_print_edition_311-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-The_Economist_print_edition-311">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the local fashion industry has grown significantly since 2000, doubling exports and increasing from a handful to about 50 established labels, with some labels gaining international recognition.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Economist_print_edition_311-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-The_Economist_print_edition-311">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">
       Literature
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_literature" title="New Zealand literature">
       New Zealand literature
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Māori quickly adopted writing as a means of sharing ideas, and many of their oral stories and poems were converted to the written form.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312">
       <a href="#cite_note-312">
        [300]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Most early English literature was obtained from Britain and it was not until the 1950s when local publishing outlets increased that New Zealand literature started to become widely known.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313">
       <a href="#cite_note-313">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although still largely influenced by global trends (
      <a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">
       modernism
      </a>
      ) and events (the Great Depression), writers in the 1930s began to develop stories increasingly focused on their experiences in New Zealand. During this period literature changed from a
      <a href="/wiki/Journalism" title="Journalism">
       journalistic
      </a>
      activity to a more academic pursuit.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
       <a href="#cite_note-314">
        [302]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Participation in the world wars gave some New Zealand writers a new perspective on New Zealand culture and with the post-war expansion of universities local literature flourished.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
       <a href="#cite_note-315">
        [303]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Dunedin is a UNESCO
      <a href="/wiki/City_of_Literature" title="City of Literature">
       City of Literature
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
       <a href="#cite_note-316">
        [304]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_entertainment">
       Media and entertainment
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_New_Zealand" title="Music of New Zealand">
       Music of New Zealand
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_New_Zealand" title="Cinema of New Zealand">
       Cinema of New Zealand
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Media_of_New_Zealand" title="Media of New Zealand">
       Media of New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ledge_Bungy,_Queenstown,_New_Zealand_01.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ledge_Bungy%2C_Queenstown%2C_New_Zealand_01.jpg/220px-Ledge_Bungy%2C_Queenstown%2C_New_Zealand_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ledge_Bungy%2C_Queenstown%2C_New_Zealand_01.jpg/330px-Ledge_Bungy%2C_Queenstown%2C_New_Zealand_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Ledge_Bungy%2C_Queenstown%2C_New_Zealand_01.jpg/440px-Ledge_Bungy%2C_Queenstown%2C_New_Zealand_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ledge_Bungy,_Queenstown,_New_Zealand_01.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Bungee_jumping" title="Bungee jumping">
         Bungee jumping
        </a>
        in the popular resort town of
        <a href="/wiki/Queenstown,_New_Zealand" title="Queenstown, New Zealand">
         Queenstown
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Music_of_New_Zealand" title="Music of New Zealand">
       New Zealand music
      </a>
      has been influenced by
      <a href="/wiki/Blues" title="Blues">
       blues
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">
       jazz
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">
       country
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">
       rock and roll
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">
       hip hop
      </a>
      , with many of these genres given a unique New Zealand interpretation.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music_317-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-music-317">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Māori developed traditional chants and songs from their ancient South-East Asian origins, and after centuries of isolation created a unique "monotonous" and "doleful" sound.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
       <a href="#cite_note-318">
        [306]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Flutes and trumpets were used as musical instruments
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319">
       <a href="#cite_note-319">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      or as signalling devices during war or special occasions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
       <a href="#cite_note-320">
        [308]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Early settlers brought over their ethnic music, with
      <a href="/wiki/Brass_band" title="Brass band">
       brass bands
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Choir" title="Choir">
       choral music
      </a>
      being popular, and musicians began touring New Zealand in the 1860s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
       <a href="#cite_note-321">
        [309]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
       <a href="#cite_note-322">
        [310]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Pipe_band" title="Pipe band">
       Pipe bands
      </a>
      became widespread during the early 20th century.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
       <a href="#cite_note-323">
        [311]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The New Zealand recording industry began to develop from 1940 onwards and many New Zealand musicians have obtained success in Britain and the United States.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-music_317-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-music-317">
        [305]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some artists release Māori language songs and the Māori tradition-based art of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Kapa_haka" title="Kapa haka">
        kapa haka
       </a>
      </i>
      (song and dance) has made a resurgence.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
       <a href="#cite_note-324">
        [312]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Music_Awards" title="New Zealand Music Awards">
       New Zealand Music Awards
      </a>
      are held annually by
      <a href="/wiki/Recorded_Music_NZ" title="Recorded Music NZ">
       Recorded Music NZ
      </a>
      ; the awards were first held in 1965 by
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reckitt_%26_Colman" title="Reckitt &amp; Colman">
       Reckitt &amp; Colman
      </a>
      as the
      <a href="/wiki/Loxene_Golden_Disc" title="Loxene Golden Disc">
       Loxene Golden Disc
      </a>
      awards.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
       <a href="#cite_note-325">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Recorded Music NZ also publishes the country's official weekly
      <a href="/wiki/Record_chart" title="Record chart">
       record charts
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326">
       <a href="#cite_note-326">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Radio first arrived in New Zealand in 1922 and television in 1960.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327">
       <a href="#cite_note-327">
        [315]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The number of
      <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_New_Zealand" title="Cinema of New Zealand">
       New Zealand films
      </a>
      significantly increased during the 1970s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_TV_328-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZ_TV-328">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In 1978 the
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_Film_Commission" title="New Zealand Film Commission">
       New Zealand Film Commission
      </a>
      started assisting local film-makers and many films attained a world audience, some receiving international acknowledgement. The highest grossing New Zealand movies include:
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Hunt_for_the_Wilderpeople" title="Hunt for the Wilderpeople">
        Hunt for the Wilderpeople
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Boy_(2010_film)" title="Boy (2010 film)">
        Boy
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_World%27s_Fastest_Indian" title="The World's Fastest Indian">
        The World's Fastest Indian
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Once_Were_Warriors_(film)" title="Once Were Warriors (film)">
        Once Were Warriors
       </a>
      </i>
      , and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Whale_Rider" title="Whale Rider">
        Whale Rider
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329">
       <a href="#cite_note-329">
        [317]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deregulation in the 1980s saw a sudden increase in the numbers of radio and television stations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NZ_TV_328-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NZ_TV-328">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand television primarily broadcasts American and British programming, along with a large number of Australian and local shows. The country's diverse scenery and compact size, plus government incentives,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330">
       <a href="#cite_note-330">
        [318]
       </a>
      </sup>
      have encouraged some
      <a href="/wiki/Film_producer" title="Film producer">
       producers
      </a>
      to film big budget movies in New Zealand, including
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Avatar_(2009_film)" title="Avatar (2009 film)">
        Avatar
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" title="The Lord of the Rings (film series)">
        The Lord of the Rings
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Hobbit_(film_series)" title="The Hobbit (film series)">
        The Hobbit
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Chronicles_of_Narnia_(film_series)" title="The Chronicles of Narnia (film series)">
        The Chronicles of Narnia
       </a>
      </i>
      ,
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/King_Kong_(2005_film)" title="King Kong (2005 film)">
        King Kong
       </a>
      </i>
      and
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/The_Last_Samurai" title="The Last Samurai">
        The Last Samurai
       </a>
      </i>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331">
       <a href="#cite_note-331">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Media_of_New_Zealand" title="Media of New Zealand">
       New Zealand media
      </a>
      industry is dominated by a small number of companies, most of which are foreign-owned, although the state retains ownership of some television and radio stations. Between 2003 and 2008,
      <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">
       Reporters Without Borders
      </a>
      consistently ranked New Zealand's press freedom in the top twenty.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332">
       <a href="#cite_note-332">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of 2011
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , New Zealand was ranked 13th worldwide in press freedom by
      <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">
       Freedom House
      </a>
      , with the 2nd freest media in the Asia-Pacific region after
      <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">
       Palau
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333">
       <a href="#cite_note-333">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">
       Sports
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_New_Zealand" title="Sport in New Zealand">
       Sport in New Zealand
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_Haka.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="600" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/New_Zealand_Haka.jpg/220px-New_Zealand_Haka.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/New_Zealand_Haka.jpg/330px-New_Zealand_Haka.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/New_Zealand_Haka.jpg/440px-New_Zealand_Haka.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_Zealand_Haka.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        A
        <a href="/wiki/Haka" title="Haka">
         haka
        </a>
        performed by the
        <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_league_team" title="New Zealand national rugby league team">
         New Zealand national rugby league team
        </a>
        before a game. A haka is a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_cry" title="War cry">
         war cry
        </a>
        by the
        <a href="/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people" title="Māori people">
         Māori people
        </a>
        with vigorous movements and stamping of the feet.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Most of the major sporting codes played in New Zealand have British origins.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334">
       <a href="#cite_note-334">
        [322]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">
       Rugby union
      </a>
      is considered the national sport
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335">
       <a href="#cite_note-335">
        [323]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and attracts the most spectators.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Organised_Sport_336-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Organised_Sport-336">
        [324]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">
       Golf
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Netball" title="Netball">
       netball
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">
       tennis
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">
       cricket
      </a>
      have the highest rates of adult participation, while netball, rugby union and
      <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">
       football (soccer)
      </a>
      is popular among young people.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Organised_Sport_336-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Organised_Sport-336">
        [324]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nzsssc_337-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-nzsssc-337">
        [325]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Around 54% of New Zealand adolescents participate in sports for their school.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nzsssc_337-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-nzsssc-337">
        [325]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Victorious
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_football" title="Rugby football">
       rugby
      </a>
      tours to Australia and the United Kingdom in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1888%E2%80%931889_New_Zealand_Native_football_team" title="1888–1889 New Zealand Native football team">
       late 1880s
      </a>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/The_Original_All_Blacks" title="The Original All Blacks">
       early 1900s
      </a>
      played an early role in instilling a national identity.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338">
       <a href="#cite_note-338">
        [326]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Horseracing_in_New_Zealand" title="Horseracing in New Zealand">
       Horseracing
      </a>
      was also a popular
      <a href="/wiki/Spectator_sport" title="Spectator sport">
       spectator sport
      </a>
      and became part of the "Rugby, Racing and Beer" culture during the 1960s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339">
       <a href="#cite_note-339">
        [327]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Māori participation in European sports was particularly evident in rugby and the country's team performs a
      <a href="/wiki/Haka_(sports)" title="Haka (sports)">
       haka
      </a>
      , a traditional Māori challenge, before international matches.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
       <a href="#cite_note-340">
        [328]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      New Zealand has competitive international teams in
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_union_team" title="New Zealand national rugby union team">
       rugby union
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_netball_team" title="New Zealand national netball team">
       netball
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_cricket_team" title="New Zealand national cricket team">
       cricket
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_rugby_league_team" title="New Zealand national rugby league team">
       rugby league
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_Socks" title="Black Socks">
       softball
      </a>
      and has traditionally done well in triathlons, rowing, yachting and cycling. New Zealand participated at the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Summer_Olympics" title="Summer Olympics">
       Summer Olympics
      </a>
      in 1908 and 1912 as
      <a href="/wiki/Australasia_at_the_Olympics" title="Australasia at the Olympics">
       a joint team with Australia
      </a>
      , before first participating
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_at_the_Olympics" title="New Zealand at the Olympics">
       on its own
      </a>
      in 1920. The country has ranked highly on a medals-to-population ratio at recent Games.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Organised_Sport_336-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Organised_Sport-336">
        [324]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OlympicRatio_341-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-OlympicRatio-341">
        [329]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342">
       <a href="#cite_note-342">
        [330]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All_Blacks" title="All Blacks">
       All Blacks
      </a>
      , the national men's rugby union team, are the most successful in the history of international rugby
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
       <a href="#cite_note-343">
        [331]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the reigning
      <a href="/wiki/Rugby_World_Cup" title="Rugby World Cup">
       World Cup
      </a>
      champions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344">
       <a href="#cite_note-344">
        [332]
       </a>
      </sup>
      New Zealand is known for its
      <a href="/wiki/Extreme_sport" title="Extreme sport">
       extreme sports
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Adventure_travel" title="Adventure travel">
       adventure tourism
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBain200669_345-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBain200669-345">
        [333]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and strong
      <a href="/wiki/Mountaineering" title="Mountaineering">
       mountaineering
      </a>
      tradition, as seen in the success of notable New Zealander
      <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Hillary" title="Edmund Hillary">
       Sir Edmund Hillary
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346">
       <a href="#cite_note-346">
        [334]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other outdoor pursuits such as cycling, fishing, swimming, running,
      <a href="/wiki/Tramping_in_New_Zealand" title="Tramping in New Zealand">
       tramping
      </a>
      , canoeing, hunting, snowsports and surfing are also popular.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SportsParticipation_347-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SportsParticipation-347">
        [335]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Polynesian sport of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Outrigger_canoeing" title="Outrigger canoeing">
       waka ama
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canoe_racing" title="Canoe racing">
       racing
      </a>
      has increased in popularity and is now an international sport involving teams from all over the Pacific.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348">
       <a href="#cite_note-348">
        [336]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">
       Cuisine
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hangi_ingredients.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1832" data-file-width="3264" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Hangi_ingredients.jpg/220px-Hangi_ingredients.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Hangi_ingredients.jpg/330px-Hangi_ingredients.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Hangi_ingredients.jpg/440px-Hangi_ingredients.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hangi_ingredients.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/H%C4%81ngi" title="Hāngi">
         Hāngi
        </a>
        ingredients
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_cuisine" title="New Zealand cuisine">
       New Zealand cuisine
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The national cuisine has been described as
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Rim" title="Pacific Rim">
       Pacific Rim
      </a>
      , drawing inspiration from Europe, Asia and Polynesia.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349">
       <a href="#cite_note-349">
        [337]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Popular ingredients or dishes include
      <a href="/wiki/Lamb_and_mutton" title="Lamb and mutton">
       lamb
      </a>
      , salmon, crayfish (lobster),
      <a href="/wiki/Dredge_oyster" title="Dredge oyster">
       dredge oysters
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Whitebait" title="Whitebait">
       whitebait
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/P%C4%81ua" title="Pāua">
       pāua
      </a>
      (abalone), mussels, scallops, pipis and tuatua (both are types of New Zealand shellfish),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350">
       <a href="#cite_note-350">
        [338]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Sweet_potato" title="Sweet potato">
       kumara
      </a>
      (sweet potato), kiwifruit, tamarillo and
      <a href="/wiki/Pavlova_(food)" title="Pavlova (food)">
       pavlova
      </a>
      , the national dessert. A
      <a href="/wiki/H%C4%81ngi" title="Hāngi">
       hāngi
      </a>
      is a traditional Māori method of cooking food using heated rocks buried in a pit oven. After European colonisation, Māori began cooking with pots and ovens and the hāngī was used less frequently, although it is still used for formal occasions such as
      <a href="/wiki/Tangihanga" title="Tangihanga">
       tangihanga
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
       <a href="#cite_note-351">
        [339]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>

     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
       Notes
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Footnotes">
       Footnotes
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="reflist columns references-column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 30em; -webkit-column-width: 30em; column-width: 30em; list-style-type: decimal;">
      <ol class="references">
       <li id="cite_note-3">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-3">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         "God Save the Queen" is officially a national anthem but is generally used only on regal and vice-regal occasions.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-1">
           [1]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AnthemProtocol_2-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-AnthemProtocol-2">
           [2]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-5">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-5">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         English is a
         <i>
          de facto
         </i>
         official language due to its widespread use.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
          <a href="#cite_note-4">
           [3]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-7">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-7">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Language percentages add to more than 100% because some people speak more than one language. They exclude unusable responses and those who spoke no language (e.g. too young to talk).
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpokenLanguage_6-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-SpokenLanguage-6">
           [4]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-10">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-10">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The proportion of New Zealand's area (excluding estuaries) covered by rivers, lakes and ponds, based on figures from the New Zealand Land Cover Database,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
          <a href="#cite_note-9">
           [6]
          </a>
         </sup>
         is (357526 + 81936) / (26821559 – 92499–26033 – 19216) = 1.6%. If estuarine open water, mangroves, and herbaceous saline vegetation are included, the figure is 2.2%.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-15">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-15">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         The Chatham Islands have a
         <a href="/wiki/Chatham_Standard_Time_Zone" title="Chatham Standard Time Zone">
          separate time zone
         </a>
         , 45 minutes ahead of the rest of New Zealand.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-16">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-16">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Clocks are advanced by an hour from the last Sunday in September until the first Sunday in April. Daylight saving time is also observed in the Chatham Islands, an additional 45 minutes ahead.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-21">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-21">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Zeeland is spelt "Zealand" in English. New Zealand's name is not derived from the Danish island
         <a href="/wiki/Zealand" title="Zealand">
          Zealand
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-251">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-251">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Ethnicity figures add to more than 100% as people could choose more than one ethnic group.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-271">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-271">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         In 2015, 55% of Māori adults (aged 15 years and over) reported knowledge of
         <i>
          te reo Māori
         </i>
         . Of these speakers, 64% use Māori at home and 50,000 can speak the language "very well" or "well".
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tereoMaori_270-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-tereoMaori-270">
           [262]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-273">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-273">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Of the 86,403 people that replied they spoke Samoan, 51,336 lived in the Auckland region.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpokenLanguage_6-3">
          <a href="#cite_note-SpokenLanguage-6">
           [4]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-277">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-277">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Religion percentages may not add to 100% as people could claim multiple religions or object to answering the question.
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-282">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-282">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         Tertiary education in New Zealand is used to describe all aspects of post-school education and training. Its ranges from informal non-assessed community courses in schools through to undergraduate degrees and advanced, research-based postgraduate degrees.
        </span>
       </li>
      </ol>
     </div>

       <li id="cite_note-4">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-4">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation report">
          New Zealand Government (21 December 2007).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.mfat.govt.nz/downloads/humanrights/5th-ICCPR-report.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights Fifth Periodic Report of the Government of New Zealand
          </a>
          <span style="font-size:85%;">
           (PDF)
          </span>
          (Report). p. 89
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            15 November
           </span>
           2015
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           In addition to the Māori language, New Zealand Sign Language is also an official language of New Zealand. The New Zealand Sign Language Act 2006 permits the use of NZSL in legal proceedings, facilitates competency standards for its interpretation and guides government departments in its promotion and use. English, the medium for teaching and learning in most schools, is a de facto official language by virtue of its widespread use. For these reasons, these three languages have special mention in the New Zealand Curriculum.
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.au=New+Zealand+Government&amp;rft.btitle=International+Covenant+on+Civil+and+Political+Rights+Fifth+Periodic+Report+of+the+Government+of+New+Zealand&amp;rft.date=2007-12-21&amp;rft.genre=report&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mfat.govt.nz%2Fdownloads%2Fhumanrights%2F5th-ICCPR-report.pdf&amp;rft.pages=89&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.btitle=New+Zealand&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.imf.org%2Fexternal%2Fpubs%2Fft%2Fweo%2F2016%2F01%2Fweodata%2Fweorept.aspx%3Fpr.x%3D26%26pr.y%3D13%26sy%3D2014%26ey%3D2021%26scsm%3D1%26ssd%3D1%26sort%3Dcountry%26ds%3D.%26br%3D1%26c%3D196%26s%3DPPPGDP%252CPPPPC%26grp%3D0%26a%3D&amp;rft.pub=International+Monetary+Fund&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-32">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-32">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation journal">
          Moodley, Y.; Linz, B.; Yamaoka, Y.; Windsor, H. M.; Breurec, S.; Wu, J. -Y.; Maady, A.; Bernhöft, S.; Thiberge, J. -M.; et al. (2009).
          <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2827536" rel="nofollow">
           "The Peopling of the Pacific from a Bacterial Perspective"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           Science
          </i>
          .
          <b>
           323
          </b>
          (5913): 527–530.
          <a href="/wiki/Bibcode" title="Bibcode">
           Bibcode
          </a>
          :
          <a class="external text" href="http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2009Sci...323..527M" rel="nofollow">
           2009Sci...323..527M
          </a>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/Digital_object_identifier" title="Digital object identifier">
           doi
          </a>

          <a class="external text" href="//dx.doi.org/10.1126%2Fscience.1166083" rel="nofollow">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.aufirst=Basil&amp;rft.aulast=Keane&amp;rft.btitle=Te+M%C4%81ori+i+te+ohanga+%93+M%C4%81ori+in+the+economy+%93+Urbanisation&amp;rft.date=2010-11&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.TeAra.govt.nz%2Fen%2Fte-maori-i-te-ohanga-maori-in-the-economy%2F6&amp;rft.pub=Te+Ara+%93+the+Encyclopedia+of+New+Zealand&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

       <li id="cite_note-130">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-130">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.webcitation.org/5vtWsfsit" rel="nofollow">
           "Minutes of the Statutory Meeting of the Chatham Islands Council"
          </a>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/Chatham_Islands" title="Chatham Islands">
           Chatham Islands
          </a>
          Council. October 2010. Archived from
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.cic.govt.nz/pdfs/councilMeetings/cic-council-statutory-minutes-281010.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           the original
          </a>

          <a href="#cite_ref-145">
           ^
          </a>

        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www2.stats.govt.nz/domino/external/PASFull/pasfull.nsf/84bf91b1a7b5d7204c256809000460a4/4c2567ef00247c6acc25697a00043f15?OpenDocument" rel="nofollow">

         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.btitle=Geography&amp;rft.date=1999&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww2.stats.govt.nz%2Fdomino%2Fexternal%2FPASFull%2Fpasfull.nsf%2F84bf91b1a7b5d7204c256809000460a4%2F4c2567ef00247c6acc25697a00043f15%3FOpenDocument&amp;rft.pub=Statistics+New+Zealand&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.aufirst=Hugh&amp;rft.aulast=Stringleman&amp;rft.au=Peden%2C+Robert&amp;rft.btitle=Sheep+farming+%93+Growth+of+the+frozen+meat+trade%2C+1882%932001&amp;rft.date=2009-10&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.teara.govt.nz%2Fen%2Fsheep-farming%2F5%2F2&amp;rft.pub=Te+Ara+%93+the+Encyclopedia+of+New+Zealand&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

         </span>
        </span>
       </li>

       <li id="cite_note-209">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-209">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          O'Hare, Sean (September 2010).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.telegraph.co.uk/expat/expatnews/7973220/New-Zealand-brain-drain-worst-in-world.html" rel="nofollow">
           "New Zealand brain-drain worst in world"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           The Daily Telegraph
          </i>
          . United Kingdom.

       <li id="cite_note-221">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-221">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Wayne Arnold (2 August 2007).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/02/business/worldbusiness/02farm.html?pagewanted=all" rel="nofollow">
           "Surviving Without Subsidies"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Times" title="New York Times">

           </a>
          </i>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            11 August
           </span>
           2015
          </span>
          .

           ... ever since a liberal but free-market government swept to power in 1984 and essentially canceled handouts to farmers ... They went cold turkey and in the process it was very rough on their farming economy
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.atitle=Surviving+Without+Subsidies&amp;rft.au=Wayne+Arnold&amp;rft.date=2007-08-02&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2007%2F08%2F02%2Fbusiness%2Fworldbusiness%2F02farm.html%3Fpagewanted%3Dall&amp;rft.jtitle=New+York+Times&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">

        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          Ranford, Jodie.
          <a class="external text" href="http://maorinews.com/writings/papers/other/pakeha.htm" rel="nofollow">
           "
           <span style="padding-left:0.2em;">
            '
           </span>
           Pakeha', Its Origin and Meaning"
          </a>
          . Māori News
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            20 February
           </span>
           2008
          </span>
          .
          <q>
           Originally the Pakeha were the early European settlers, however, today ‘Pakeha’ is used to describe any peoples of non-Maori or non-Polynesian heritage. Pakeha is not an ethnicity but rather a way to differentiate between the historical origins of our settlers, the Polynesians and the Europeans, the Maori and the other
          </q>
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.aufirst=Jodie&amp;rft.aulast=Ranford&amp;rft.btitle=%27Pakeha%27%2C+Its+Origin+and+Meaning&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fmaorinews.com%2Fwritings%2Fpapers%2Fother%2Fpakeha.htm&amp;rft.pub=M%C4%81ori+News&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-258">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-258">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation book">
          Socidad Peruana de Medicina Intensiva (SOPEMI) (2000).
          <i>
           Trends in international migration: continuous reporting system on migration
          </i>
          .
          <a href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">
           Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
          </a>
          . pp. 276–278.
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+Zealand&amp;rft.au=Socidad+Peruana+de+Medicina+Intensiva+%28SOPEMI%29&amp;rft.btitle=Trends+in+international+migration%3A+continuous+reporting+system+on+migration&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.pages=276-278&amp;rft.pub=Organisation+for+Economic+Co-operation+and+Development&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </li>
